Since that meeting, a very important event has taken place. The York City Council has unanimously passed a resolution supporting the creation of an East Yorkshire county on the lines of my Amendment. This decision by York opens up the possibility of an ideal county authority.
May I show how it would measure up to the criteria of the Government's White Paper Cmnd. 4884. The White Paper says: Local authority areas should be related to areas within which people have a common interest through living in a recognisable community, through the links of employment, shopping or social activities, or through history and tradition. If that is the ideal to which the Bill aspires, the proposed East Riding county must be the answer to a Minister's prayers.
First, let us examine it for community of interest. If my right hon. Friend will look at a road map of East Yorkshire he will get the immediate impression that all roads lead to York, and his impression will be right. York is the centre of our communications, both road and rail. When I stand on York station waiting for my train to London I see a high proportion of people from the East Riding on the platform. Within a radius of 10 miles of York many people look for their work, for the city has a variety of prosperous industries.
Country people look to York for their shopping. Farmers look to York for the livestock market—and a very modern market we have. A large area of East Yorkshire is served by the York hospitals. People from the area included in my Amendment come to York in their thousands for the races, for the festival, for the theatres, and York is our educational centre, too. What I have said applies not only to the people in the East Riding but also to those who live in the area immediately south of York down to Selby at present in the West Riding but included in the Amendment.
The White Paper requires "common interest by history and tradition". York and the East Riding have exactly that. When £2 million were required to restore York Minster, seven-eighths of that money
was found in Yorkshire. York is our city and ought to be our county capital In area, the proposed county would not be excessive at 1,300 sq. miles, especially as it is well served with roads—and pleasantly uncrowded roads at that.
Its finances should be sound. The key figure of rateable value is £36·35. This is certainly adequate, especially as it is an area virtually free of chronic and expensive environmental problems such as urban renewal. The population at 357,000 is not large, but it is sufficient and comparable in resources with new counties such as Somerset. Agricultural counties are by their nature never very large in population. Administratively, the county adds up to a thoroughly manageable proposition.
With regard to community of interest, this new county represents a well-nigh perfect situation. A large but manageable county area, based on a fine city, well placed geographically, with all the resources and communications demanded of a county capital, a rôle for which history has certainly qualified the ancient city of York. So much for viability.
The Minister has asked for evidence that there is a demand for the proposed county from the people who live in it. As to York itself, I leave its Member to put its case. With regard to the large county areas contained by the constituency of Bridlington and my own constituency of Howden, I am convinced of overwhelming support for an East Riding county.
7.30 a.m.
As the Minister needed reassurance, I quote two more independent sources. The East Riding County Council has sent out a simple and straightforward questionnaire, to which nearly 29,000 people have responded. This has indicated that over 90 per cent. of the people in the East Riding wish to have a separate county of East Yorkshire—separate, that is, from Humberside or North Yorkshire. These are the uncomplicated reactions of members of the public to a simple proposition.
The county council also arranged for an entirely separate and scientific poll of public opinion to be carried out by national opinion polls. This was a cold-blooded exercise seeking views on a random basis on a number of selected points. This poll shows that 75 per cent. believe
that there should be a separate county of East Yorkshire. The fact that Hull people were included may account for the difference between the 90 per cent. view of East Riding people who responded to the questionnaire.
In an area as wide as this it is hardly possible that there could be a more overwhelming majority against the proposals in the Bill and in favour of the simple and obvious proposition of providing another county for another set of people.
As an East Yorkshire county is so obviously wanted by East Yorkshire people, it only remains for me to establish that such a county would not harm our neighbours.
The clerk to the North Riding County Council, in a letter to the Secretary of State, asserts that the effect of my Amendment would be to reduce the area, the population, and the rateable value of North Yorkshire. North Yorkshire is at the moment embarrassingly large—the largest county of all. To reduce it from 2 million acres to 1,700,000 acres could only be advantageous in terms of efficiency of administration. To try to administer this vast area from Northallerton, with its abysmally poor communications, is a daunting prospect.
I ask the Minister to imagine the lot of, say, a county councillor from the Selby area who had to go to Northallerton for his meetings.
As to population, at 418,000 and with a rateable value per head of £35·79, this reduced North Yorkshire is a thoroughly viable proposition.
In respect of our northern neighbour, therefore, our conscience is clear. My Amendment would improve the ease of administration and merely remove the proportion of the population who have far more in common with the East Riding of which they have always been a part.
With regard to our Southern Humberside neighbours, our conscience would be equally clear. The Amendment would bring their population down to 691,000—a perfectly satisfactory figure. The Humberside area would be reduced to one which really has some affinity with the River Humber. The rateable value would work out at over £40 per head. Humberside would lose a large number of unwilling constituents from such areas as Pocklington and Driffield who have nothing in common with Hull and to
whom Brigg, Scunthorpe and Grimsby might as well be in a foreign land.
To sum up, I believe that the Amendment could result in an admirably well balanced county, offering a compatible association of agricultural, holiday and minor industrial areas and the City of York. It could provide a real and workable balance between town and country. Though one of the smaller counties with a growing population of about 350,000, it would be by no means the smallest and would have the great advantage of offering electoral areas of reasonable size and good local representation on the county council. All this could be achieved without injury to neighbouring authorities.
I commend the Amendment to the House.

After 17 hours I managed to listen assiduously to the speech by the hon. Member for Howden (Sir P. Bryan). At this hour I have no intention of making a Committee speech and I will pass only a few comments on what the hon. Member said, and refer also to one of the other Amendments being discussed. The speech to which we have just listened and, I guess, others, too, judging by the presence of other hon. Members on the Government benches, is pure sabotage of the Government's proposals which have the full support of the hon. Members on both sides, including all the Humberside Members. It is not a matter of party politics. Local government produces some queer debates and some unusual alignments. All of us were glad to hear the Minister say unequivocally in Committee that Humberside has come to stay.
Earlier we heard an hon. Member stating that he was searching for the best kind of Government. I felt like shouting out, "Is there a social geographer in the House?" because in committee we were seeking socio-geographical areas or communities and the Humber Estuary is an ideal example, particularly lower down on both banks. The Government believe that Humberside will succeed and so do I. Hence, I deplore the snivelling effects of this kind of Amendment put down at this stage of the Bill.
They are backwoodsmen.

They are the Bourbons of Louth and the shellbacks of Howden. They are like two whales wallowing about in shallow water, and the Humber has deep channels, too. We have seen the effects of misunderstanding and jealousy between the two banks of the Humber. Today the Lord Mayors, the town clerks and the councillors of the Grimsbys, the Scunthorpes, the Beverleys and the Haltemprices are coming together in a new spirit of unity and saying that the scheme will go on. They are giving the legislators the encouragement to continue with the Bill.
In counter distinction we have the attitude of certain hon. Members opposite. Unless we support the Government and our civic leaders, Humberside will not advance and prosper whatever happens in the coming years. Formerly we lacked the means of uniting both banks but within a year or two we shall have three links. There will be the ferry, and the high level bridge at Hook when the M18 comes through, and we shall have the Humber Bridge which will cross a little to the West of Barton-upon-Humber. There will no longer be the excuse that there is no contact between, and no unification of the two sides.
Already all the ports of the Humber are under the Humber Board. We are seeking similar unity of our local authorities by the Government's proposals. It would be tedious to cite all the relevant surveys on the region and one is enough to support our case. The Humber Feasibility Studies of 1969 say that we have a future and a potential if we all pull together and do not adopt the attitude of the snivelling Amendments.
I come to the flibbertigibbet scheme of the hon. Member for Louth (Mr. Jeffrey Archer). What an amazing concoction! To describe it as a wrecking Amendment would be polite. If these hon. Members get their way they will reduce the hopeful local authority that we are expecting into a mere gut on both sides of the Humber, whereas we want a unison of the urban centres, of Scunthorpe, Hull and so on, with the hinter land behind them. Squires in stubble fields of Lincolnshire are the kind of people who are behind the Amendment of the hon. Member for Louth.
The hon. Member for Howden spoke of York as an ideal capital. He is like the
Grand Old Duke of York. He can march to the top of the hill, but he has not even one man to march with him. [Interruption.] I am waiting for his speech, and I have more faith in my hon. Friend the Member for Kingston upon Hull, East (Mr. Prescott) to support me.
This is a non-party issue. I am authorised to say on behalf of the hon. Member for Haltemprice (Mr. Wall) that, in contradistinction to what was said about support in East Yorkshire, not merely he but his Conservative Association on the west side of Hull are in favour of the Bill. We must not be churlish. The Government have tried to carry out the pledge they gave in Committee. I am certain we shall get what the Minister promised us in Committee.
My hon. Friend the Member for Goole (Dr. Marshall) has had to go North, but I know that he also opposes this wrecking Amendment, and I am sure that he would also oppose the Amendment to come. He has authorised me to say that the people of Goode and Osgoldcross do not want the Amendment. He also wishes to congratulate the Government on what they are doing and to stress the need for co-operation after the debate.
I also oppose Amendment No. 382, which concerns what was known as the Kimball Line some time ago. I will not say "Maginot Line", but it was just as bad, just as out of order and just as stupid in the light of history as the Maginot Line.
I oppose Amendment No. 994 as well. It is strange to see how attempts have been made to distort towards the north, and towards the west of Grimsby, the boundary line given to us in Committee We should have had in the Humberside area those parishes which have a connection, whether through shopping or work, with the urban district of Brigg and the boroughs of Grimsby, the Humber bank at Immingham and the petro-chemical works and elsewhere.
I do not understand, in the light of the undertakings we were given, why it is that this distortion has gone north of the A18, the main highway east to the coast. I assume it is because there is a certain E1 Diablo who dwells north of this line. It is important that Conservative Members
should be able to maintain contact with their supporters in their Conservative associations.

Nothing said by the hon. Member for Kingston upon Hull, West (Mr. James Johnson) has persuaded me to change my mind. I do not wish to move Amendment No. 382, in view of Amendment No. 914.
I would urge my right hon. Friend to resist Amendments Nos. 965 and 79. The argument advanced that the A18 should be the county boundary is not valid. There is no case for making a county boundary of a road.
I am grateful to my right hon. Friend for putting down Amendment No. 914, which restores the Caistor Rural District Council. The Bill line split Caistor for no other reason than that it was the line proposed in the Radcliffe-Maud Report. That dealt with a different system of local government. There is no justification for the Bill line. In no case are the urban and rural districts split. Amendment No. 914 proposed by my right hon. Friend restores the Caistor Rural District to Lincolnshire and has taken note of the popular feeling expressed in the public opinion poll as a result of the remarks made during the report stage of the Bill, when 77·1 per cent. of the people in this rural district wished to remain in Lincolnshire.
I thank my hon. Friend for his intention to give the Urban District of Brigg a chance to come into Lincolnshire if it wished. The hon. Member for Kingston upon Hull, West is right. Brigg Urban District Council no longer wishes to go into Lincolnshire. My right hon. Friend at this last moment, despite the feelings of the people expressed in a public opinion poll, decided to leave the Urban District of Brigg in Humberside.
The Isle of Axholme has said that it wished to go into Humberside. It is not for me to deal with the problems of Grimsby, Cleethorpes and Louth. They have their own Member to put their point of view.
I do not wish to appear churlish at this stage after the Minister's Amendment in favour of Lincolnshire. I must place on record the final view of Lindsey
County Council. Today the members of the Council are as much opposed to Humber-side as ever. They remain unshaken in their conviction that the interests of local government are best served by the one county of Lincolnshire. The Humber is no mere boundary. It is a barrier. The river divides. Only time will see who is right, the Lincolnshire Members or the hon. Member for Kingston upon Hull.
Everyone in Lincolnshire is grateful to my right hon. Friend for ending the uncertainty and for finalising the boundary of the county. I am grateful to him and his colleagues for the sympathetic way in which they have handled this delicate matter and the way, insofar as it lay within their power, in which they have taken note of local feelings.

I address my remarks to the proposal advanced by the hon. Member for Howden (Sir P. Bryan) who wished to unite the city of York with certain areas of the East Riding to form a new East Yorkshire county area.
I represent a city which is one of the oldest in the country, going back 1,900 years, with one of the oldest charters in the country, going back over 600 years, and therefore a city which naturally, when it came to losing its county borough status, looked at these proposals with some reluctance. The proposals came forward in much the same way from the Maud Commission. It was notable that Mr. Senior, the dissenting member of the Maud Commission, who put forward other proposals in respect of this area, put forward similar proposals to those of the majority of the Commission and very similar to those of the Government. It is notable that when the Government first advanced their proposal for the area they, too, adopted an area not unlike the original Maud scheme.
I am bound to come to the conclusion that from either point of view there is much to be said for including York in a North Yorkshire area which spans most of the area between the sea and the Pennines. Geographically and under the present proposals it is by far the biggest area in the country. It has over 2 million acres and is the only county to have anything over that figure.
That is not the end of the matter. It has a certain unity in population and in
the kind of influences that are brought to bear over the whole area. Most of the peripheral parts of this gigantic area are moorland or open countryside.
The major areas of population are around the Vale of York, from York to Harrogate and from Ripon down to Selby. Is is therefore, a natural centre for cohesion and in my view will make a more cohesive and viable area. My only doubt about the original Maud proposals and the Government White Paper was that, despite the geographical size of the area, its rateable value was so low. One of the things which has plagued the City of York over the years in advancing its services has been the low rateable value of the city, which has meant that we have under-invested in capital growth and we have found great difficulty in extending our services, particularly in relation to planning and services. This new area offered considerable hope.
In addition it has many other opportunities, given a certain imaginative vision on the part of elected representatives, as one of the major tourist areas of the country. It has, first of all, the Yorkshire Dales, than which there is no finer scenic area in the country. It has the North Yorkshire moors and the Vale of York. It has two seaside resorts, now that Whit by has been brought in, and three major conference centres of York, Scarborough and Harrogate. It has about half-a-dozen major castles, four or five of the major monastic remains in the country, including the major existing Cistercian remains. If a local authority governing the new North Yorkshire area did not exploit those advantages to the full it could blame only itself.
Although I faced the future of a city with a history of York submerged in an area of that nature with a certain reluctance, I nevertheless received a certain uplift over the imaginative openings in such an area. Unfortunately the City Council of York, both Labour and Conservative groups, have been unanimous that such openings are to be denied by the kind of parochialism which has been accepted in the initial planning stages by those responsible in the North Riding County Council.
It seems to me a tragedy that this opening should be so denied. It is assumed
by all planning the future of the North Yorkshire area from the North Riding that Northallerton will be the county headquarters of the area—a small market town 30 miles north of one of the major cities of Europe. This great city is to be governed from this parochial backwater merely because the old North Riding County Council headquarters have always been there and offices exist there and the new North Yorkshire Area does not wish to envisage building offices in York although there is room there and scope for a major architectural achievement. There is the nub of our problem—on the one hand, all the possibilities this new opportunity gives us and, on the other, the limited vision of those who will apparently control this matter.
The Government could have dealt with this. They could have identified the new county headquarters in this Bill, but neither this Government nor their predecessor wished to take that decision out of the hands of the new local government unit. The Government have decided to keep the existing ward boundaries for new local government representation in the new county set-up which means that the new urban areas in North Yorkshire will be under-represented. In North Yorkshire, York will get 13 seats out of about 89 in the new urban area. If it had had more, perhaps it would have had more say in where the new headquarters should be.
Therefore, the councillors looked elsewhere to see whether some other unit would give greater viability and greater hope of adopting York as the new headquarters. When the proposal came from the East Riding for a new area, they looked at it with favour. They supported it.
I regret that I cannot go along with that view. I still maintain that the most viable area is the North Yorkshire area. I can only hope that the new council will rise to the opportunity and not deny to York its proper place as the new headquarters. Hidden in the argument is a strong case. These are arguments my council would wish to put forward. I can only add these defects. The new East Yorkshire area would be one of the smallest in the country. It has the smallest population and rateable value.
Councillors in York ask, "So what?" They say that it would be about the same size as the East Riding and three times the size of York at present. However, we are not living in the same age. We are told that the new units are deliberately larger because they will be able to attract better men and materials to give better service to their citizens. If York were to belong to one of the smallest areas in population and rateable value, the possibility of better services for the citizens of York would be limited. I do not wish to deny to my electorate the opportunities for advancement that would come from belonging to a bigger unit.
8.0 a.m.
The new North Yorkshire area, on the other hand, is the seventeenth from the bottom in rateable value and the twentieth from the bottom in population, so that, for all its great geographical size, it is roughly middling in terms of population and rateable value. It cannot, therefore, be said that it is too big. It is not. For this reason if for no other I would be apprehensive of the future of York in the new East Yorkshire.
I do not have to say very much about the effect on Humberside. Most of it has already been said by my hon. Friend the Member for Kingston-upon-Hull, West (Mr. James Johnson), but clearly it would have some repercussions on Humberside. Humberside would still be a large unit, and a viable unit, but it would be smaller than it need be, and its potential would be reduced.
Therefore, with great reluctance, I cannot share the view of my City Council that we should go into East Yorkshire. But this whole experience indicates where the dangers are if we allow the old parochialism to dominate the new opportunities. I know that the Minister cannot accept the proposal for the East Yorkshire area, but I hope that he will indicate to those who will be governing the new North Yorkshire area that they must look at this new unit with completely fresh eyes. It will include Harro-gate—and I welcome that addition because it will give greater strength to the new unit—a good slice of the West Riding, York, Selby and a fair slice of the East Riding. Therefore, it is not the old North Riding, but a completely new venture, and it should be looked at with those eyes. If it is, York and those areas
of the East Riding that will join us will have no fears for the future.
On the other hand, if we are to be dominated by the narrow-minded attitudes that have prevailed so far, we shall have a great deal to fear from what will ensue. I hope that the debate will have been useful in warning the new councillors in the North Yorkshire area of their responsibilities towards York and the East Riding.

I rise to support the Amendment which stands in my name, and Amendment No. 77.
I have great personal admiration for the hon. Member for Kingston-upon-Hull, West (Mr. James Johnston), yet I was shocked to hear some of his comments about the attitude of those on our side of the bank. I have just as much right as anyone else to represent our people in this House and, if they feel strong on an issue, to stand up and say so. It is neither introvert nor backward, when 82 per cent. of the people want something and 18 per cent. do not, to stand up here and defend the 82 per cent.
The people of Lincolnshire would be shocked to hear that they are jealous of Hull. That is the last thing we are; we have never been jealous of Hull—we have been considerably more successful, but not jealous. I do not represent the pheasant-shooting people of Lincolnshire. I have never shot a pheasant or been on a shoot in my life. As for the comments of Lord Yarborough, I have met him only once, when we had a cursory conversation in which Humber-side was never mentioned. On all those counts the hon. Member for Kingston-upon-Hull, West is wrong.

I beg the hon. Member for Louth (Mr. Jeffrey Archer) to look at the situation in the context of the future. He may well say tonight that he is a mirror an image or echo of tens of thousands of his constituents. He is a Member of Parliament. Will he please face this in the setting of Humberside as a whole and think less about his own circumscribed parliamentary constituency?

I assure the hon. Gentleman that in these circumstances what I put forward is not only the view of my
constituents but also the view I have reached at the same time. This is not a view I am presenting on their behalf and not feeling myself.
Lincolnshire is a successful county, and the strength of the county is the south bank of the Humber; the strength in rateable value of land and general finance, and in many ways the strength of the people in that area. It is that very area which will be taken away from Lincolnshire, leaving the rest of the county weak and rather second rate. Our rateable value will take us second from the bottom in the league table if this proposal is not amended. We were told originally that we were to have County 22. This was greeted by my constituents without great affection, but we were convinced at the end of the day that it was perhaps the best thing. Then at the last moment—and I believe this is the only case where it happened—we discovered that there was to be a Humberside County.
One of my quarrels is that none of us knew that this was to happen until the last moment. One discovered that it had been turned upside down after spending the last year and a half convincing people that County 22 was a good thing.
If I could have my way I would go back to County 22. But I realise, having talked to the Secretary of State and the Minister, that this was never on. So we made representations that the right hon. Gentleman might consider the compromise put forward by my hon. Friend the Member for the Isle of Ely (Sir H. Legge-Bourke). The Minister said he would take note of certain things and of the strength of feeling in the area. I did not push him too hard on this, because I thought that if the strength of feeling was only 60–40 then he would be in a position to say so. But at the end of the day 60–40 can turn the other way when they know the facts.
In the two areas I am defending, Cleethorpes and Grimsby rural, we had a poll. In the first 56·6 per cent. voted and in the second 73·2 per cent. The vote of 73·2 per cent. is considerably higher than the poll at the General Election and 56·6 per cent. is a little below. What was the result? There were 83·3 per cent. in favour, and a vote of that size where I come from is something which should be taken seriously
and taken into consideration. There was a vote of 16·7 per cent. against. When we had that vote they said the poll was fixed and rigged. So Grimsby decided to have a vote to see how fixed and rigged it was.
Grimsby is desperate to get into Humberside on any terms and the Grimsby Council took a whole page in the local paper. It said "We must go into Humberside" and "Humberside will be better for us". It listed the advantages from the top to the bottom of the page. They held their poll but they did not get 83·3 per cent. saying they wanted to join Hull, but 87·1 percent. saying they did not want to join Hull, despite the council trying to bribe them into it.
I hope the Minister, in reply to the debate, will say why we want a Humberside county. However introverted the hon. Member for Kingston upon Hull, West thinks we on the south bank are, I must tell him that we are doing very well, and we were doing very well before we were told we had to join the hon. Gentleman. We do not want to join him since we have done pretty well up to now.
We have one of the most successful ports in the country, namely Immingham. It has no rivals in terms of its returns and its success grows year by year. That port does not want to join Hull or be dominated or controlled from Hull. When the new council is set up in Hull and has its headquarters there, the voting on that council in percentage terms will be 65 members from the Hull side and 35 from the Lincolnshire side. If the hon. Member for Kingston upon Hull, West were on that council as the member for Immingham and had only 35 votes against 65 on the other side, I am sure that he would be frightened about what would happen on the other side of the river when things were not going the way they wanted.

Does not the hon. Gentleman now understand why I turned on him a little earlier and called him a Bourbon? He is living in the past. We want to live for the future. Let us make an effort to work together, live together and pull together for the future.

I take the point, and in fairness the hon. Gentleman must admit that there is an element of truth in what I say. If the hon. Gentleman's area were a great success story, I would want to join him. But Hull is a failure, whereas we are a success. He is going to take our success and perhaps turn it into a failure. That is a genuine fear on the part of my constituents. My constituents genuinely do not want to join the port of Hull and I sympathise with them. I hope the Minister will say in his reply what percentage would influence him in terms of the number of voters when we bear in mind the figure of 83·3 per cent. for compared with 16·7 per cent. against.
I am also here to defend Cleethorpes. Cleethorpes is a borough whose sole industry is that of tourism. It is a small borough that looks south, has been governed from Lincoln and has tourism as its main activity. It is not interested in the bank as such and has no connection with the bank. The people in Cleethorpes feel strongly about being governed from Hull. They also have a natural fear that their borough will suffer because it is not part of the bank and has no connection with the work of the bank.
I take the point made by the hon. Member for Kingston upon Hull, West about co-operation. If it works, I shall be the first to stand in the House and say "I was wrongs—it has worked, and is a great success." But if we find the people of Cleethorpes saying that it is getting worse and worse and that they cannot get across the bridge every day because of the fog—and all the meetings will take place in Hull—then that is a different matter.
There is a feeling among Hull Members that if there is a bridge across the river, it automatically means that both sides will work together. But it is strange that everybody on their side is saying that this is the case, but that nobody on our side is saying it. They find it rather strange that we do not automatically welcome the bridge; that we do not automatically want to go to Hull, and that we do not automatically want to be governed from Hull.
8.15 a.m.
The hon. Member for Kingston upon Hull, West made a strong attack at the
beginning of his speech, which I immediately defended. I end on the same note. It is a privilege to represent the people of North Lincolnshire; it is a privilege to represent the people of Cleethorpes, and of Grimsby rural district. They do not want to go in. I hope that the Minister will give a clear indication why we need a Humberside council, and cannot have County 22.
Secondly, I hope that he will tell us why such a high vote did not influence him and, thirdly——
What about a referendum?

It is obvious that the hon. Gentleman does not know what the word "referendum" means.
I hope that the Minister will reply, because even at this last moment my constituents would accept a Humberside authority if there were a really good case for it. I ask the Minister to accept my Amendment and allow Cleethorpes and Grimsby rural district to stay in Lincolnshire, so that it can remain a viable and sensible county. It would not take much from Humberside; Humberside would still be a viable proposition, but it would allow both Lincolnshire and Humberside to have a genuine share of the cake and a genuine chance to remain viable, whereas the present situation represents a triumph for Humberside, as a successful large county, but a total collapse of the old Lincolnshire.

I listened with interest and a considerable degree of amusement to the speech of the hon. Member for Louth (Mr. Jeffrey Archer). I have come to the conclusion that the people with the forked tails and horns on their heads are not Lincolnshire imps but the people who live in Hull. The greatest thing that could happen is to build a bridge and create a new county, in order that we may be in a position in which we can enlighten the people from the south bank and try to show them, somehow, that we share many of the same problems and that some of us have the same desire to represent our constituents as does the hon. Member for Louth. Unfortunately, when the hon. Member represents his consituents he wears blinkers. He can see only the narrow, selfish advantage of
the moment. He fails to see what development may take place in the estuary.
If the hon. Member for Howden (Sir P. Bryan) and the hon. Member for Louth had their way there would be little left of Humberside. There would be a nibbling here and a nibbling there, and we should be left with a small littoral along the river bank, equivalent to the Gallipoli beachhead and nothing more.
The hon. Member for Howden does his constituents a grave disservice in advancing his scheme. Had he suggested that East Yorkshire went to the North Riding I could have understood. I would, have regretted it; but I could have understood. Had he suggested that more of the East Riding should go into Humberside I could have understood. But to take East Yorkshire out and make it such a poor area—to maintain the old sores and the old suspicions between town and country that have been magnified on Humberside between Hull and the East Riding far more than in any other area—because we have a large city surrounded by a great agricultural area, a little blob of red surrounded by a sea of blue, has created suspicion, a lack of co-operation, and a failure to take the opportunity to use the benefits that could have come to the north bank after the war, when the south bank was developed.
The failure was due to the suspicion of the backwoodsmen of the East Riding and Beverley County Hall—those reactionary people who are now going to do a further disservice to the people who live in the Riding. I have a great affection for those people. Both my brother and I tried to represent them. There is certainly a real opportunity here for people in the East Riding and in Hull to come together, to forget their old suspicions and to work together for something better for them all.
The hon. Member for Louth asked "What is this vision of a Humberside county? What is this thing?" In that he showed his own lack of vision. What it is is a story about the development of the only great virgin estuary we have left, the Humber, of the only area where we can stop and, instead of having piecemeal development like there was on the Mersey, the Tyne or the Thames, we can sit down and plan a great future for
both sides of the Humber because we still have the areas to develop.
We have on both banks a very good balance between industry and agriculture, between town and city. Admittedly we have a lot of urban renewal in Hull and many problems about declining industries, but it must be remembered that in North Lincolnshire and the East Riding we have the same problems of declining industries. It is the same problem of declining industry and of employment. As men leave the land in the East Riding and Lincolnshire they must be found jobs just as much as people who lose their opportunities on the docks, in Silcocks or some thing of that nature. Therefore, it is the same problem we have to deal with together.
We have this potential through this great estuary, if we seek to use it, to develop the deep water channels, to develop the Spurn Bight and to develop a great port and industrial complex for ourselves. Whether we go into Europe or not—I hope at this late hour that we shall not—that potential is there to be developed, in or out.
As for the hon. Member for Louth saying "Immingham is my little port and that is the best of the lot", I remind him that Immingham was developed by public enterprise and public money as part of Humberside docks complex. It is part and parcel of the whole unit which is used and administered together. Instead of saying "What will happen to my little port at Immingham", the hon. Member should have been saying "Look. We use these docks, we develop these docks and we do things about Howdendyke, Selby and Gunness and we say you are to use registered dock labour, otherwise we will not let you be used as ports."
It is that sort of thing that creates problems on the docks on our side. The hon. Member should realise it, because public enterprise and nationalised industries put the money into Immingham, took the coal from Hull and put it into Immingham, took the iron ore and put it there to take it into Scunthorpe. This was done by public money and public enterprise and did not have a great deal to do with people who lived on the South Bank.
The opportunities for development on both banks will be tremendous. With the bridge our case for a polytechnic will be unassailable. Think of what this can mean for people on both banks. It should be remembered that there is not a polytechnic from Middlesbrough right the way down the East Coast until well into East Anglia. There are opportunities there for improving the social services on both banks, for the administration and the cultural work on both banks. It is all there with the bridge and the new road networks which are coming. These will give a strength, a force and a vigour to this new Humberside county.
"We do not want it on our bank" says the hon. Member for Louth. Certainly there are many people on his side of the bank who want it. Scunthorpe wants it, as do many other places. As they see it develop, they will say "Thank goodness we did not listen to the blinkered opinions of the hon. Member for Louth but instead we stopped, we went in, we went in with proper suspicions because this was a new idea and a new adventure." It is, however, a new idea and adventure which hon. Members like those for Howden and Louth could do a great deal to make into a real adventure, a real joining together, a real co-operation in going forward to create in our new Humberside a thriving, well-balanced population with opportunities for all its people to develop it. Instead, we have listened to carping criticisms and the backswoodsman attitudes of hon. Members on the Government side against their own Government's very wise decision.

I will deal first with the Amendments in the name of my hon. Friend the Member for Howden (Sir P. Bryan) as they deal with the northern part of the new county of Humberside and the proposed new non-metropolitan county of East Yorkshire with a population of some 392,000. The effect on neighbouring counties would be to reduce Humberside by 178,000, leaving a population of 668,000 in the new Humberside county and it would reduce North Yorkshire by 225,000 to a figure of 401,000.
The plain intention of the Amendments is to perpetuate the East Riding and at the same time to avoid being involved
with Hull. I say without hesitation that in so doing the Amendments would make a shambles of the Humberside county proposed in the Bill, a shambles by cutting off Hull and Haltemprice from their area of influence to the north and the industrial development to the east.
The East Yorkshire county proposed by my hon. Friend would cut across the economic links of Hull and Haltemprice. Humberside is not a metropolitan county for which tightly drawn boundaries would be appropriate; it is a non metropolitan county and should be combined with different rural areas. To draw the boundary right up to Hull violates the principle that non-metropolitan counties should be a union of town and country.
The links between Hull and East Yorkshire are strong. The East Riding County Council denies that there is an affinity between the East Riding and Hull, but that is nonsense.
Where do people earn their living?

Where do people earn their living, as the hon. Member asks? There is a great flow of workers into Hull from East Yorkshire and it is significant that there is a great flow of population out from Hull into East Yorkshire. That exchange of population makes it all part and parcel of a county which we now have as the new Humberside county.
There are not only population links but geographical links. Except at a distance of some eight miles to the west, where the Wolds rise some 500 feet, there is no physical barrier between Hull and the most populous part of East Yorkshire, and to the east there is quick and easy access to the northern and eastern sides of the East Riding. To the west roads and railways cut round the southern end of the Wolds at Ferriby or cross them west of Beverley to Market Weighton. There is therefore an affinity geographically.
There is certainly an affinity economically. Hull and Haltemprice are an enormously powerful economic magnet on the rest of the East Riding.
The strength of the combined economic pulls of Hull and Haltemprice may be gauged by the fact that, as I have mentioned, a substantial proportion of the residents of East Yorkshire in the area
which we have now included in the new Humberside county find employment in Hull and Haltemprice. But not only the present economic links show an affinity between Hull and Haltemprice and the rural areas behind them. The future economic links, although they cannot be forecast with certainty, are indicated in the feasibility study of Humberside which was made in 1969 by the Central Unit for Environmental Planning. The study assumed that the total population for North Humberside would rise to 902,000 by the turn of the century and suggested four schemes for where future development might take place. Looking at those growth areas or schemes as anticipated in that feasibility study, it would be quite impossible to imagine them without Hull and Haltemprice as the hub or centre from which they should develop.
My hon. Friend the Member for Howden said that York was a very important centre of communications. Of course, it has been a famous railway junction for many years. It is a centre for a wider area than East Yorkshire in that respect. But on the road pattern York certainly is off-centre. It cannot be looked upon as the centre of growth areas conceived by the feasibility study of Humberside.
The reactions of the local authorities have shown that the East Riding County Council's proposals go against the wishes of most of its district councils. Since the county council made its proposals known, Derwent for example is about the only one to have written in their support. There are many who are against the idea. The North Riding County Council has written opposing the attempt to take territory from the new North Yorkshire and attacking the East Riding County Council's publicity campaign for its proposals. Since the campaign of the East Riding for this separate East Yorkshire County Council, in my Department the reaction from the public has been nil, either for or against. We have received no correspondence from the public on it.
I cannot advise the House to accept the Amendments of my hon. Friend the Member for Howden. They would be wholly contrary not only to the new Humberside county and its concept, but to the concept of non-metropolitan counties in the Bill.
I pass to the Amendments dealing with the southern boundary of the new Humberside county. These fall into two groups, those concerned with the Grimsby—Clcethorpes area and those concerned with the Glanford Brigg—Caistor area.
There are two sets of Amendments which deal with the Grimsby—Clee-thorpes area. Nos. 76 and 77 would take Cleethorpes borough and Grimsby rural district out of Humberside, and those are the Amendments referred to by my hon. Friend the Member for Louth (Mr. Jeffrey Archer). There are also Amendments tabled by the hon. Member for Goole (Dr. Marshall) which have not been discussed. Therefore, I shall not touch upon them.
The effect of the Amendments of my hon. Friend the Member for Louth would be to wreck that part of Humberside which falls in my hon. Friend's constituency. It is probably quite incidental but possibly quite deliberate that the effect of the two Amendments would be to leave Grimsby county borough as an isolated area of Humberside surrounded by Lincolnshire territory. We should have a sort of Bangladesh in the middle of Lincolnshire. Whatever the cause, the effect would be planning nonsense——

I must make it clear that the only reason why I did not include Grimsby was that I did not feel that I had the right to include it. If I had my choice, it would be County 22. But I do not represent Grimsby, and I felt that I did not have the right to table an Amendment including Grimsby.

I can only deal with the Amendments as they are. It is a blemish of the present system that the two towns are not in the jurisdiction of the same major planning authority. To perpetuate their separation would be a major disservice to local government.
I use these harsh words to my hon. Friend partly because he uses immoderate language, though quite rightly, in defence of his constituents in putting their case. However, he sometimes terrifies me when he gets going and I have to use these harsh words in return.
My hon. Friend's argument seemed to be, "I am all right, Jack." I ask him to persuade his constituents that they can bring strength into this new Humberside County. Cleethorpes Borough Council and its inhabitants are as vociferous as my hon. Friend the Member for Louth and against any link with Grimsby. However, Cleethorpes and Grimsby are, in all but name, the same town with nothing physically to distinguish where one ends and the other begins. I am sure that without a map a stranger would not be able to guess that the boundary between the two runs down the middle of Park Street. Therefore, I ask my hon. Friend to bring Cleethorpes into the new Humberside County with grace, to realise it is bringing in strength, and that without it there would be a blemish on this plan for the new county.
I need not deal in detail with those Amendments which refer to the area of Brigg, Glanford Brigg Rural District and Caistor. Having looked at these Amendments and the various formulae which have appeared on the Order Paper and in my correspondence—I assure the House there have been many formulae for this boundary through Glanford Brigg Rural District and Caistor—the most reasonable one which seemed to satisfy the people of the area most was to retain the whole of Caistor Rural District just as it is in Lincolnshire.
I know that at a point this boundary cuts across a trunk road from Grimsby to Scunthorpe. However, it does not matter so much that a trunk road, which, after all, is maintained 100 per cent. by central Government, should cut across two counties. We have retained neither the Kimball nor any other line, but the Scunthorpe and Grimsby line. I am determined to keep those two places within the new Humberside County.
Amendment No. 914 merely puts Caistor Rural District into Lincolnshire and I ask the House to accept that one Amendment on the southern boundary, to bring to a certainty that that is now the southern boundary of the new Humberside, and to reject the other Amendments.
I beg to move Amendment No. 683, in page 200, line 23, at end insert: 'except the area in Hertfordshire'
With this Amendment it will be convenient to discuss Amendment No. 684, in page 200, line 35, at end insert: In the administrative county of Essex, the urban district of Waltham Holy Cross.

Weturn from the broad and major issue of the new Hum-berside to a much smaller but, in my view and that of my right hon. and hon. Friends, equally important issue of rectification of county boundaries to which we want to call the Minister's attention and ask for his support.
The object of the Amendments is to take the urban district of Waltham Holy Cross, which includes Waltham Abbey, out of the County of Essex and add it to the County of Hertfordshire. One may regret that the Member for that area has not added his name to the Amendment, but we do not feel it right that proposals which are deserving of consideration should not be considered simply because the hon. Member for Epping (Mr. Tebbit), who is in his place, is not a supporter of them. It seems to us that there is here something of an injustice which could be rectified relatively simply and, as there have been a number of modifications and alterations to county boundaries during the passage of the Bill through Committee and even on Report, I am sure the Minister will not take the view that the proposal is ruled out of court simply because it involves this change in county boundaries.
There is one immediate point of logic in trying to re-unite the Walthams, that is to say, the urban district of Waltham Holy Cross with Waltham Cross on the other side of the River Lea which is part of Hertfordshire. I understand that a little more than a year ago there were discussions between Waltham Holy Cross Urban District Council and authorities on the other side of the River Lea in Hertfordshire about possible arrangements for a linking, and it was probably only the publication of the White Paper which stopped those discussions, which I understand were friendly. I gather that there was some hope that there might have been
this rational linking together of these small urban communities.
8.45 a.m.
Geographically, there is the division of the River Lea, but that is more a means of grouping two communities together than a dividing line. There is no difficulty about movement from one side of the river to the other. A development in which I have always taken a good deal of interest is the Lea Valley Regional Park, with the possibility of new developments right along the course of the river. Gradually—far too slowly for some of us—there is the exciting concept of new communities growing up and new recreational facilities based on developments on both sides of the river. This is an example of the communities on either side of the river coming together.
In 1969 the Royal Commission on Local Government stated: When the Lea Valley Regional Park is established, the links between east Hertfordshire and neighbouring parts of Essex will be further strengthened. The future motorway from London to Bishops Stortford will also effect development in and around the Lea Valley and, in our view, the whole of this area should be administered as a part of a single local government unit.

I am sure that the hon. Gentleman will want to make it plain that that motorway at that time was to go up the Lea Valley, whereas it now goes up the Roding Valley. The unit of local government to bind together Waltham Abbey and Waltham Cross in that proposal was also to bind together Epping and Chigwell.

The hon. Gentleman has put his point of view. It is still the view of the community in Waltham Holy Cross that there should be this link and that the two communities should be joined with Hertfordshire. In their view, the communications across Epping Forest are nothing like as simple as those they would have into Hertfordshire. Part of the argument is that the effective boundary is much more Epping Forest than what is no barrier at all—the River Lea. The point is made with regard to communications that, if the link were to be, as they wish, with the county town of Hertfordshire—Hertford—the distance is only 12 miles, as against the distance of 25 miles to their county town of Chelmsford.
The social links are in many cases already there. It would mean that the Essex District 6 without Waltham Holy Cross would have a population of just over 100,000, and Hertfordshire District 7, with the inclusion of Waltham Holy Cross, would have a population of nearly 86,000. This is further evidence of the good sense and logic of the link.
The discussions were initiated a little time ago. There is strong feeling in the area in favour of the proposal, despite the strong campaign against it—a strong campaign which appears to have raised many illogical points, including questions about hospital facilities, which are in any case organised on a regional basis.
It is a pity that a matter of this importance, like other matters we have discussed during the night, has to be taken at the end of this long sitting. The Secretary of State may have had a convenient rest for a while and may have returned to us completely refreshed. We have not seen quite so much of him during the night as we have of other Ministers. For him this may not be a problem. For the body of hon. Members concerned with the matter, it may be that the more suitable course would be for the Minister to say that he is willing to look further at the matter, that fuller and more proper consideration will be given to it, and that possibly a proposal along the lines of the Amendment can be accepted in another place.

I rise to offer a few observations in the matter, because although I am not a Member representing the exporting element, if the Amendment were carried I should be a Member representing the element into which Waltham Holy Cross would be incorporated. The odd thing about the Amendment is the extreme remoteness of those whose names are on the Order Paper in its support from the scene and locality with which we are here concerned.

I explained at the start that it seemed to me and to my right hon. and hon. Friends that we had a right to bring to the House a proposal of this sort, even though the hon. Members whose constituencies are affected did not necessarily offer their support to the Amendment. The matter is one of suffi-
cient importance to warrant the matter being discussed in our view.

I am not querying the right of right hon. Gentlemen on the Labour benches to table such an Amendment. I only observed that as we are here concerned very much with matters of local interest, with local matters, it is perhaps a shade paradoxical that it should be tabled by right hon. and hon. Members representing Deptford, Birmingham, Cardiff, Widnes and Bishop Auckland.

The right hon. and learned Gentleman will at least receive a reply from the hon. Member for Meriden (Mr. Speed) who comes from even further a field. What the right hon. and learned Gentleman says is nonsense.
My hon. Friend the Under-Secretary will reply when he has heard the local views of my hon. Friend the Member for Epping (Mr. Tebbit) and myself.
My hon. Friends and I have heard the views of the local authority concerned, although I admit we have not heard the views of the hon. Members concerned.

Nor the views of the authorities in my constituency who are intimately affected by the proposals. Be that as it may, I think that it is fair comment that the proposers of the Amendment are very far removed from the local scene and in the event the Amendment has been moved by an hon. Member whose name does not even appear among the five names beside it. I think the good citizens of Waltham Holy Cross might well say, if it is in their everyday idiom, "Non tali auxilio"—that they would not wish to succeed with the help of right hon. Gentlemen on the Opposition side.
This is a matter involving local considerations and the onus must be on those seeking the change of boundary because the change would involve the alteration of the county boundary in a form not previously recommended at any stage, a single piecemeal alteration not related to a general pattern. To discharge that onus successfully they would have to show, first, very strong support from public opinion not only in Waltham Holy Cross
but in the areas affected, that is to say in Cheshunt—Hoddesdon, the present tenants of District 7. They would have to show a compelling community of interest and they would have to show that the suggested fusion is in conformity with the underlying principles of local Government reorganisation. I submit that this case is not made out and cannot be made out.
Of course, there is some support in Waltham Holy Cross for this fusion, but there is also a good deal of opposition within it. The support is by no means the general consensus that the hon. Gentleman suggested. I shall leave my hon. Friend to evaluate that, since his constituents are affected.
Certainly, there is no reciprocal public support in what would be the receiving districts of Cheshunt and Hoddesdon. There the interest in the matter is appreciably less than it probably is in Waltham Holy Cross. Indeed, I have received very little correspondence on it, except for a well-written letter from the Secretary of the Cheshunt Labour Party in favour of the proposals, to which I give very close and conscientious attention. I cannot say that there is any evidence of a general desire in either Cheshunt or Hoddesdon for this fusion to be effected. There is a strong feeling against any future threat of absorption into the Greater London Council area. This awakens vivid memories of 10 years ago, when we had a protracted and successful struggle to prevent the absorption of Cheshunt into the GLC. There are those who feel that the linking of Waltham Holy Cross with Cheshunt would necessarily reopen that unwelcome possibility. On that aspect of the matter there is certainly no passivity or tepid feeling in Cheshunt. It is strongly against that possibility.
There are mixed feelings in Essex and there is no manifest desire for the change in Hertfordshire. It is not exactly a case of joyous wedding bells. Here we have a suitor with honourable intentions, no doubt, but not very strong, with ardour far from unqualified, and the addressee of these advances exhibiting symptoms of indifference or reluctance going far beyond the requirements of maidenly modesty or of playing hard to get. Parliament should certainly not make a
marriage from such elements. It would be a shotgun marriage, with the right hon. Gentleman's finger on the trigger.
The memorandum from Waltham Holy Cross stresses the shared services. There are a number of shared facilities, as would inevitably be the case where there is a physical contiguity, but none of these activities—shopping, using the telephone, travelling from the railway station, buying the paper—will be affected if Waltham Holy Cross remains in Essex. It can hardly be suggested that the shopper will pause at the bridge over the River Lea and refrain from going to shop in Waltham Cross merely because he is entering another local authority area.
In any event, the matter should not be looked at solely from the point of view of Waltham Holy Cross. There is no benefit claimed for Cheshunt or Hoddesdon. If there is a case for the revision of the Hertfordshire-Essex border, it should be treated more comprehensively. The Hoddesdon Council has indicted such possibilities as the absorption into Hoddesdon of parishes within the Epping and Ongar Rural Districts. Further north still, the Essex villages to the east of Bishops Stortford would lend themselves better to a general pattern of revision of county boundary if such were to be thought appropriate. They have a wider community of interest, because they are villages that look to Bishops Stortford in all matters connected with village life—a very high percentage for shopping, marketing, hospitals, and general recreational and cultural facilities. Yet no Amendment has been put down in respect of any of those possible revisions of the county boundary and one is left to wonder why.
9.0 a.m.
It is true that the proposed District 7 is relatively small in numbers, with a population of 71,000 against the prescribed range of 75,000 to 100,0000. That does not prove the case for additions, because there is a rapidly expanding population. If there is any addition it should not be done by the incorporation of another urban district, especially one to be further urbanised by Greater London development.
What is required is the addition of rural elements to correct the imbalance between town and country and not to
aggravate it as this would do. That could be done without any alteration of county boundaries by proposals to incorporate various parishes in District 7 which are already in Hertfordshire. Those proposals have been put forward and merit the consideration by the Commission which they are entitled to receive. The effect of the Amendment would be to prevent their consideration by the Commission and to confine the District necessarily within a rigid urban framework. That is contrary to the principle of local government reorganisation and to good planning. Therefore it should be rejected on those grounds and on the balance of advantage to the communities affected.

I, in common with my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hertfordshire, East (Sir D. Walker-Smith), wondered what my constituents in Waltham Holy Cross would think about the names on this Amendment. It seems to me that if this amendment were to be put down by hon. or right hon. Gentleman who do not represent the area, they might have found someone who lived a little closer to it or knew a little more about it. They might even have found someone who knew that the motorway proposed at the time of the Royal Commission is not on the route that has now been established.
I could hardly believe my ears when I heard that a strong campaign had been mounted against the proposal being considered, without any mention of a £4,000 public relations consultant's contract going, without the full knowledge of all members of the Council, to a public relations firm to shove the idea down the throats of my constituents against their wishes.
I have known the town of Waltham Abbey, the centre of the Waltham Holy Cross district, since I was a child. Its west boundary is the River Lea. There is still only one crossing of that river in the whole urban district council area of which we are speaking. It is a congested crossing, as are the crossings to the north and south. One would imagine it was the mouth of the Amazon by the number of crossings there are of it at this point.
The boundary to the south is London. To the east is the Epping Forest and the
Copped Hall Estate, and to the north the small villages in Epping and Ongar Rural District Council which separate the district from Harlow.
I know this countryside and the town, neither from the public relations blurbs nor from the one-sided reports from one group of people. I have walked, fished, boated, fallen off my first bicycle and motor bicycle there. I even impaled my first motor car on a tree there. One cannot do that without getting to know the countryside.
Perhaps my hon. Friend bent his first aeroplane there!

My right hon. learned Friend the Member for Hertfordshire, East suggests that I may have bent my first aeroplane there. I did fly in that area for many years and I know the lie of the land there. I know the towns and villages there very well indeed. I know its lanes, its footpaths, its pubs its churches and, above all, I know the people who live there—a privilege which has been denied to those proposing this Amendment. I have no axe to grind about the place at all. It will not even be in my constituency after the next General Election, but to the local people this is important.
It was not I who went to them to say "Oppose this." It was they who came to me asking me to oppose it. They pointed out to me that Waltham Holy Cross dates back over 900 years, that it has a great history, that the forest of which we have spoken was in those days known as the Forest of Essex—how strange to put it into Hertfordshire! Later it became known as Waltham Forest and later still Epping Forest. They feel bitter that all this is brushed aside by a PR blurb which has been fought by the local council.
I was first approached in this matter some considerable time ago by some local councillors who came to see me and said that they wished to see their urban district council of Waltham Holy Cross linked with Cheshunt and the town of Waltham Cross, rather than with Epping. I pointed out the difficulties, the highly problematical case and I said that I did not wish to oppose it, I had no particularly strong views about the matter.
Since the White Paper and the Bill proposed local government reform to be based primarily on existing counties and county boundaries they would have to make a strong case and to go back to the report of the Royal Commission with its comments about the suitable area in the Lea Valley was highly irrelevant. I told them I took the view then, as I do now, that to put a county boundary on the east side of the town instead of on the west side would do nothing to change the problems inherent in any town on the edge of a county. It merely transfers the problems to a different county. I made it plain then, and it is still my view, that if the people of the area wanted this change I would support it.
Then I heard very little more and throughout the long and highly publicised battle of the north-east boundaries of the county of Essex there was not a word from any of my constituents about any wish to change the county boundary in their area. After the local elections in the spring members of the council again asked me if I would support a move to link Waltham Abbey with Hertfordshire in a local government area.
I pointed out that this had been left pretty late—to propose a change in the county boundary. I said I would support it if certain conditions were met. The conditions were, first that the Essex County Council accepted at the very least, even if it did not support the change; secondly that the Hertfordshire County Council similarly accepted at the very least the change and thirdly that Cheshunt Urban District Council, the prospective partner in Hertfordshire, should also accept if not welcome the change.
Above all, I said that the people in the Waltham Holy Cross Urban District Council must tell me that they wanted that change. I pointed out to the members of the council, perhaps rather foolishly, that I had not had a single letter to suggest that the people of the area wanted this. The councillors then very smartly nipped out and engaged a firm of public relations consultants and asked them as I understand it, to discover reasons why they wanted to join with Waltham Cross and also to whip up support for the proposal.
I have here a copy of the leaflet which was then delivered, to the fury of many of my constituents, to all the houses in the area. I say "to the fury" because they thought it was rather an expensive leaflet and they resented that it had no indication of who published it, although clearly the council had had a hand in it because it was discovered in envelopes which, among other things, had the rateable values of property stamped on them where this had rubbed off the council records.
This said: It is logical to go with Herts, if you agree, support the campaign by writing, yourself, to: Mr. Norman Tebbit, M.P., The House of Commons, Westminster. That is the sort of thing which no Member in his right mind would ask for, for fear of having to answer all the letters. It goes on: …and by signing the petition". The case put rests heavily on common interest with Hertfordshire. It is said that newspaper and entertainment facilities are shared. My right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hertfordshire, East pointed out that this had nothing to do with local government.
Postal and telephone services are shared, but so they are by many in Waltham Holy Cross and the postal address of some is not in Essex or Hertfordshire, it is London, E.4. What do we make of that? Is Waltham Abbey to join Greater London? That would most certainly be resented by everybody there. Bus services and railway station are shared. Yes, but where does the railway line run? Not to Hertford, the county town, but into London. That is case for what the people do not want. Police, social security, and public utilities are shared by both districts.
The gas main, I confess, runs out of Hertfordshire into Waltham Abbey, but that hardly makes for strong feelings about local government.
Does my hon. Friend appreciate that the other proposed partner in the district is not within the Metropolitan Police area but in the Hertfordshire Police area—that is Hoddesdon?

I did not appreciate that, because the stuff from the public relations consultants told me that the rest of the area is in the Metropolitan Police area.
It is said that there are sewage disposal and many other services in common. Yes, Waltham Cross is in the same sewage precept area as Waltham Holy Cross—the Greater London precept area—so what has this to do with the move of my constituents against their will into Hertfordshire? It is difficult to say.
Having received this, I was asked to support an Amendment which now appears in the names of far flung hon. Members from other parts of the country. I pointed out that none of the criteria I had set out had been satisfied.
Essex County Council do not wish this change to be made. As my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hertfordshire, East has explained, neither Hertfordshire nor Cheshunt says that it would be a satisfactory arrangement.
Above all, the people of Waltham Abbey have not indicated to me any support for this proposal.
It may well be that there is some support for it. To be absolutely sure, I wrote recently to the urban district council. I wrote, to make sure that I would be on good ground in this matter, on 27th June. I said: If the council itself has any communications on the matter from my constituents I would of course be pleased to take those also into consideration. I had a letter back promptly, on 29th June, telling me that the clerk was away at a conference and my letter would be placed before him on his return, but nothing to say that the council had any information that the people wanted this move.
I read in the local Press that a petition has been raised. As the local Member of Parliament I do not have it; I do not know who does have it. I have asked the council whether they have it, but they do not seem to know.
At the beginning of the campaign, which has been run very efficiently by public relations consultants—so it should have been; the people of Waltham Abbey are being charged a hefty feet to be told that they want to do something that they do not want to do—the leaflet I have spoken of was distributed and it asked people to write to me as their Member of Parliament. They did. It was a good leaflet, effective, and I would not wish to
go too far in quoting extracts from the letters I have received. I will summarise the views expressed in them.
As a result of the campaign, I received 58 letters opposed to the change, including letters representing the collective views of two branches of the Women's Institute, the Chamber of Commerce, the Waltham Abbey Historical Society and the Upshire Village Preservation Society, and a letter from a Minister of the Church. I also received a school exercise book which contains 872 names as a petition against the change. It was not hawked round from door to door; it was not taken round by paid canvassers to the local fairground while the fair was in progress as I understand another petition was. It just lay upon the counter of a small news agent's shop in the centre of the town, and 872 customers came in and signed it. Petitions can mean anything or nothing, as we all know, but I also received 413 small slips from pamphlets which were handed round at no cost to the ratepayers by a group of people who did not like the way they were being railroaded by PR consultants. They were all posted to me and bore in total the signatures of 651 electors of the district. No doubt some were among the 872 who signed the petition. I should not be surprised if some of the names were also on the petition expressing the opposite view. These things often happen! I also received a letter from a lady who was uncertain about the merits of the proposal but was a little uneasy in case the boundary change meant that she would not be able to go shopping in the other county.
Here, I should show the House the results of £4,000 worth of public relations consultancy directed towards persuading my constituents to write to me saying that they want to go to Hertfordshire. It is contained in this bundle of 18 letters. We all know that the Post Office is not what it was; perhaps one letter got lost on the way; perhaps I or my secretary mislaid one; perhaps there were 20; but, at £200 a letter, these are the most expensive letters I have ever received. Certainly they are amongst the most expensive letters that the residents of Waltham Abbey have ever had to write.
I am hoping that if the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Deptford (Mr. John. Silkin) is to add anything to
the case being made for the Amendment he will make a generous offer—or I will make an offer to sell him the letters at £200 a time, provided that he will return the money to the people of Waltham Abbey who have had to fork out this £4,000 against their will.
I thought that this was absolutely disgraceful. There are 18 of them. One came from the Hertfordshire branch of the Labour Party so I am not sure whether we should not reduce the number to 17. One came from the Enfield Highway Co-operative Society. I should explain to Opposition Members who do not know the area that although the headquarters of Enfield Highway Co-operative authority is a Middlesex address, it is within the Greater London area. It does have a branch within Waltham Abbey. I have had a considerable amount to do with that branch of the co-op because, despite protests from all over the town, the historical and amenity so cities and the local council, its main contribution to life in Waltham Abbey has been to allow a beautiful historic building which it owns in the centre of the town to degenerate into a slum, presumably in order that it can be knocked down to develop another supermarket block.
Among the letters is one from a minister of the church opposing the change. There were two in favour of the change. One minister was such a newcomer to the town that he angered his congregation by supporting the change and the church wardens wrote to me saying I was not to pay any attention to him: he was a newcomer and his views did not represent those of his parishioners.
The most bizarre letter of all was from a gentleman who did not live in my constituency, but he did arrange cricket fixtures for local cricket clubs. He said the cricket clubs had more fixtures with teams in Hertfordshire than in Essex, which established that community of interest which dictated that Waltham Abbey be moved from Essex to Hertfordshire.
The idea that a cricket lover could wish to move to a county which does not have a cricket team is bad enough, let alone that he could put it forward as reason for a change in county boundaries. My right hon. Friend the Member for Hertfordshire, East says that Hertfordshire has
a cricket team. That we must give him. But it is not a team to which anyone, other than those members who have to support it, would want to belong.
What is all this about? What are the compelling reasons? I am sorry if the right hon. Gentleman the Member for Deptford looks at his watch. He tabled an Amendment about my constituency. He might have the grace not to be irritated by the fact that I wish to speak about the affairs of my constituency.

When the hon. Member for Epping (Mr. Tebbit) has been in the House a little longer he will find out that the Front Benches have a duty to perform, and he will find out that we put down Amendments to the Bill on information we received. Although he probably does not know, he will find out that there have been 2,600 Amendments to the Bill. A great proportion of them have been in the names of myself and my hon. and right hon. Friends, some of whom come from Wales.
On the other side of the House the Secretary of State for Wales, who represents an English constituency, would agree that what we are trying to get in the Bill is the best possible solution to local government reorganisation. Bitter, cynical imputations against other people's fairness of mind is not the way to get that result.

I accept what the right hon. Gentleman says. The ostentatious examination of watches when I am speaking about affairs of my constituents makes it appear to me that there is a move to cut down what I say about the Amendment put down by the right hon. Gentleman. That does not come under the heading of courteous behaviour that I am being lectured on.
If a change had to be made, the case would have to be clearly made out both that the advantages would outweigh the disadvantages and that the people in these areas wanted the changes. The material gain is almost nil. The people of the area do not want this change and they would be scandalised if it were forced on them, even at the cost of £4,000.
I ask the House and my hon. Friend to reject completely this absurd idea of moving a county boundary which has existed for a thousand years, when it is
obvious that the town wants to stay in the area in which it is.

The hon. Member for South Shields (Mr. Blenkinsop), for whom I have great affection, developed a powerful and compelling case on these Amendments. There were contributions by my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hertfordshire, East (Sir D. Walker-Smith) and by my hon. Friend the Member for Epping (Mr. Tebbit) who went fully into the situation.
It is true that none of the neighbouring local authorities favours the change put forward by the hon. Gentleman. Essex County Council does not want to lose Waltham Holy Cross; Hertfordshire County Council takes the line that the present boundary should be maintained and might possibly be reviewed later; Chigwell UDC does not want Waltham to go; and Cheshunt UDC, with which Waltham would inevitably be joined in a new district, opposes Waltham Holy Cross. None of the local authorities wants it.
My hon. Friend the Member for Epping dealt at some length with the various activities on the public relations side. I say nothing about that, but so far as transfer is concerned we have had representations from the Epping Forest Constituency Labour Party, the National Mobile Home Residents' Association, and 53 private individuals. Against the transfer are Waltham Holy Cross Conservative Association, Waltham Abbey Chamber of Commerce, Waltham Abbey Historical Association, Friends of Historic Essex, Sewardstone Village Hall Committee, Sewardstone Women's Institute, Upshire Women's Institute, and 163 private individuals.
