On the balance of the information we have had it would appear that there was not an overwhelming view by residents that the transfer should take place.
The arguments used revolved round the argument used in the Redcliffe-Maud Report three years ago. Those arguments have been dealt with by my right hon. and learned Friend and it can be said that Maud was considering a much larger area at the time. There are no arguments we can see which would incline us to accept this Amendment and I must ask the House to reject it.
I beg to move Amendment No. 73, in page 200, line 30, at end insert: Herefordshire The Administrative County of Herefordshire. I think it might be convenient to take also the following Amendments:
No. 74, in page 200, leave out lines 31 to 34.
No. 104, in page 203, line 33, at end insert: Worcestershire The county borough of Worcester The administrative County of Worcestershire except the boroughs in West Midlands.

The effect is to keep two separate counties of Herefordshire and Worcestershire instead of having one combined county of Hereford and Worcester, which is the Government's present intention. In fact, there are three local authorities at present, Herefordshire, Worcestershire and the City of Worcester.

Perhaps I should say at the outset that everyone agrees that the City of Worcester should be included in the County of Worcestershire. As far as I am aware, there is no disagreement here or in Worcestershire about his part of the Government's proposals.

The Bill also removes the boroughs of Halesowen and Stourbridge from Worcestershire and transfers them to the West Midlands metropolitan area. This is not welcomed in Halesowen or Stourbridge or the county as a whole, but I think that this transfer is agreed on both sides of the House. The situation has therefore been reluctantly accepted in Worcestershire, and this group of Amendments would not change this part of the Bill.

I make these points because I want the House to appreciate that when I refer to Worcestershire in the rest of my speech, I mean the area which includes the City of Worcester and excludes Halesowen and Stourbridge.

When the Maud Report was published it recommended a further division of Worcestershire. The northern half was to be included in the West Midlands
metropolitan area and the southern half was to be linked with Herefordshire. This recommendation was accepted by the Labour Government, but was generally opposed in Worcestershire. It is only fair to the Government to say that the decision to retain Kidderminster, Bromsgrove and Redditch in Worcestershire is a great relief to many people in the area. But this is not the case in Herefordshire. The merger between Herefordshire and Worcestershire is intensely unpopular, and I will return to this point in a few moments.

First, I should like to deal with the other arguments. When I moved this Amendment in Committee, I put forward two basic arguments for keeping Herefordshire and Worcestershire as two separate counties. I shall not repeat those arguments in full this morning. Briefly, they were that there is a tremendous difference between the two counties in character and size. I explained that the local geography, especially the Malvern Hills, separates the two counties into two distinct areas.

Although it is true that both Herefordshire and South Worcestershire are rural areas, this is no longer true of North Worcestershire, and I would remind the House that the Government are including North Worcestershire in this new county. There is no doubt that Worcestershire is much more widely involved with industry and commerce than is Herefordshire. The two counties have different problems. Herefordshire has the problems of a sparsely populated rural area, which is changing slowly. Worcestershire has the problems of an area which is not only more dependent on industry but is also growing very rapidly, especially in the north, where we have a new town and a great deal of other housing development. The addition of Herefordshire, with its different problems, can only be a distraction for Worcestershire in dealing with our own problems.

The second argument against this merger lies in the widespread opposition to it among the councils and the people of Herefordshire. I do not think that there can be any doubt about the sincerity and strength of this feeling. I gave the Committee a long list of organi-
sations which had expressed their opposition. I emphasised that it was not only the county council; there were letters from the farmers, the county landowners, the local government officers, the doctors, the lawyers, and the architects—and many citizens had expressed their opposition at parish meetings.

The Government's reply was to the effect that whatever the people of Herefordshire may think, their county is too small to keep its independence. The Government do not rely on financial criteria—probably because they realise that Herefordshire would have a rateable value per head which is higher than four Welsh counties and two English counties in their original proposals. Instead, the whole of the Government's case rests on population. The Government have accepted a figure of 250,000 as the minimum population for a county in the new organisation. Worcestershire meets this criterion, but Herefordshire has only 140,000.

The Government say that this is not enough, and in Committee the Minister pointed out that under the Government's proposals the smallest county in England would have a population of 270,000. That is true as far as it goes. But it is also true that next door to Hereford, across the border in Wales, the Government are creating a new county of Powys, with a population of only 100,000—a little more than two-thirds of the population of Herefordshire.

The Government say that they are treating Herefordshire differently because it is more densely populated. In fact, Herefordshire is three times more densely populated than is Powys. But Herefordshire is one of the most sparsely populated parts of England. Indeed, the density of population in Worcestershire is nearly four times that in Herefordshire, and according to the Worcestershire County Council the disparity is likely to increase.

That is the whole point of the argument. Herefordshire and Worcestershire are different areas. The only thing that they have in common is that they are separated by the Malvern Hills. The Government cannot draw a line along the Welsh border and say that Powys is viable with a population of 100,000 and Herefordshire is not viable with a population of 140.000.

That was the situation when we had the discussion in Committee. The Government defeated an Amendment that I moved, but the people of Herefordshire have not been idle since the Committee considered the Bill. The county council has reaffirmed its opposition, and the views of the district councils have been clarified.

I should like to go into some detail about this because after the Standing Committee there was some controversy. I said in that Committee that I understood all district councils were opposed to the merger. In fact, that was a misunderstanding, and the clerk of Hereford City Council has gone to some trouble to confirm the precise views of each district council in Herefordshire. At the last count only three out of 12 district councils can be taken as supporting the merger. Those three councils represent 20 per cent. of the population of Herefordshire. This means that most of the district councils, representing 80 per cent. of the population of Herefordshire, are opposed to the Government's plans.

Since the debate in Standing Committee the people of Herefordshire have organised a petition which opposes the merger. In view of the references that were made during the previous debate on an Amendment affecting Essex, perhaps I should say that the petition was organised by the people of Herefordshire and not by a public relations consultant.

The petition was presented to the Prime Minister at Easter. It had then been signed by more than 60,000 people. I estimate that that is about 60 per cent. of the electorate in Herefordshire. Even allowing for people who may have signed more than once, there must be about 60,000 signatures and only 72,000 people voted for all political parties in the whole of Herefordshire at the last General Election. Whatever doubts the Government may have had when this subject was discussed in Standing Committee five months ago, there is no room for doubt now.

It is crystal clear that the overwhelming majority of the people in Herefordshire do not want this merger. They have had plenty of time to think about it. It is three years since the Maud Report. It is two years since the Labour Government's White Paper. It is one
year since the Conservative Government's White Paper. It is eight months since the Bill was published and five months since the Standing Committee considered this part of the Bill, and the people of Herefordshire still want to be an independent county. Yet the Government seem determined to ride roughshod over their wishes. Without one word of criticism of the services provided at present by Herefordshire County Council, with out any Minister responsible for this part of the Bill having visited the County of Herefordshire as far as I can find out, the Government are insisting——
I am sure the hon. Member would now like to withdraw that. I certainly have visited the county.

I will certainly withdraw it if the right hon. Gentleman will assure me that he visited the County of Herefordshire and discussed these proposals with representatives of the county council and district councils.
I visited Herefordshire. Among others I certainly discussed it with councillors and county councillors.

I am delighted to have that assurance and withdraw my comment, which was based on information I had received. My information, perhaps I should explain, was that although the Herefordshire County Council had asked for a delegation to meet the Secretary of State, its representatives indeed met him and had an informal discussion here lasting only 15–20 minutes. The fact remains that in spite of any discussions the county has had with the Secretary of State himself, the people of Herefordshire, the County Council of Herefordshire and the district councils of Herefordshire are overwhelmingly opposed to this merger.
So what about the views of Worcestershire, which is to provide three-quarters of the population of the new county? In Committee I explained that Worcestershire County Council had accepted the Government's proposals but did not advocate them. The Worcestershire County Council has gone much further now. In March it issued a public statement which repeated that the Government's proposals were accepted by Worcestershire County Council but added that the proposals were not welcomed by the council. The
council explained that it had accepted the Government's proposals only because they were better for Worcestershire than the recommendations of the Maud Report.
That, however, is not the issue. The choice is not between, on the one hand, the northern half of Worcestershire being detached from the county and the southern half joined with Herefordshire and, on the other hand, a merger of the whole of Worcestershire and the whole of Herefordshire.
The choice before the House this morning is between a merger of two counties and the retention of two separate counties. Worcestershire County Council has publicly stated that neither the county nor the City of Worcester would in the least mind if Herefordshire retained its independence. Indeed, I understand that Worcester City would prefer a new county based on the existing county area of Worcestershire, but has decided not to object to the addition of Herefordshire.
The only justification for the Government's proposals must be that the merger would benefit Herefordshire; but most people and most councils in Herefordshire do not believe that it will. The overwhelming majority have rejected the merger, but the Government continue to insist that they know best. It is unfortunate that the fate of Herefordshire is being debated at this time of the day on a Friday after an all-night Sitting, but even at this hour I urge the Government to change their minds.

I know that the hon. Member for Bromsgrove (Mr. Terry Davis) put forward his Amendment in good faith, but I do not agree with his arguments. Nor do I agree with his view of the feeling in Herefordshire. Six months have elapsed since this controversy rose to its full height, and in Herefordshire the mood of local councils and the people is gradually changing.
I agree that at the time local opinion was vocal, genuine and heart felt, but my constituents, in North Herefordshire, are beginning to look at the proposed amalgamation in a different light now that it has been explained to them in more detail. My right hon. Friend the Secretary of State for the Environment personally came to Leominster where he held a large public meeting on 19th May, when he explained in great detail why the
merger was so vital for Herefordshire and how by amalgamation Herefordshire could become a viable county.
The hon. Member for Hereford (Mr, Gibson-Watt) and I have already managed to do one thing—we have managed to change one of the Government's rules by having no double-barrelled names. As is known, the name of Hereford will now remain and the new title will be 'the county of Hereford and Worcester'. It will also retain its postcode.
During the past six months, I have held meetings all over my area and met representatives from the county council, the urban and rural district councils and the parish councils, the NFU and the various women's organisations. I wanted to explain why I believed that in the long term amalgamation was the best solution for our county, and I think that that has got through.
In Herefordshire we have a long and proud history. We have old and famous traditions. We have deep-rooted loyalties and, above all, I believe hon. Members will agree, we are one of the most beautiful and unspoiled counties in England.
During the campaign that the hon. Member mentioned—"Save Herefordshire"—there was a petition signed by more than 60,000 people out of a population of 139,000. But many of the people who signed the petition were, I believe, under the misguided impression that not only the name but the entire county was to sink without trace, that we should completely lose our identity, that we should be completely wiped off the map. That is not what is to happen. Our county will not change its character or its identity.
9.45 a.m.
I believe sincerely that by amalgamating we can become a stronger and more viable county. We shall all still live in the county of Herefordshire. The Hereford Herd Book will continue to flourish. So will our farmers, our cider and our hops. We shall still be able to cheer to new and greater victories the Hereford United football team, which has done so extremely well of late.
It would have been a very easy and popular thing for me to have resisted the proposed merger, but it would not have
been honest, realistic or forward looking. As their Member of Parliament, I have a responsibility to my constituents to see that all our present excellent services are maintained and continually being improved.
If Herefordshire tried to go it alone with improving services, it would mean a greatly increased rate and a much larger rate support grant. Already the Exchequer support is 72 per cent. But by amalgamating there would be some financial advantage in rateable value terms. Whereas the rateable value per head in Herefordshire is at present £34·5, that of the proposed new area would be £39·6.
I must give the reason why I supported the Government's proposals for Area 17. Not only do I believe that they are right and the best solution in the long term, but I want to change while all the other changes in local government are taking place, and to carry out this major reorganisation in an orderly fashion.
It may be that we could survive on our own for a few more years—possibly another five. Then we should face the unknown and, in the end, we might have to go "cap in hand" to the Government of the day. Possibly they would be a less sympathetic Government, even a Government of another colour. In five years all the other local changes would have taken place and everyone else would have settled down in their new authorities. Herefordshire would be at the Government's mercy. It could be carved up and parcelled out in small pieces to neighbouring counties such as Gloucestershire, Shropshire and Worcestershire, thus erasing the county of Hereford from the map for ever. That is why it would be completely wrong to try to go it alone for a few more years.
The argument has often been put forward that if we go into Worcestershire, we shall be dominated and outvoted on every issue. The draft proposals have allocated 23 councillors for Herefordshire and 67 for Worcestershire. But, being a countryman and knowing a little about human nature, I am confident that on the whole, the farming and rural representatives would gang up. More than 65 per cent. of new councillors will come from rural or agriculture-orientated areas. Their basic interests are the same and,
having myself been in local government, I believe that they would work and vote together on many issues.
The hon. Member for Bromsgrove asked what were the benefits in our going in. Worcestershire has a population of 417,000. As the hon. Gentleman said, much of South Worcestershire is very like Herefordshire. Basically, we are both agricultural areas. What is more, we both want to build up more tourist interests.
The hon. Gentleman made great play about the Malvern Hills separating us. Let us be fair. They are not mountains. They are not such a barrier. I live at the foot of the Malvern Hills in Herefordshire in a village called Eastnor. Always in the past our two counties have worked closely together in great harmony. Two very good examples are the Three Counties Agricultural Show and the Three Choirs Festival. Our characters are much the same. The communications by road and rail, although not perfect, are adequate.
By joining Worcestershire we gain two great assets. One is population and the other is industry, both of which we lack in Herefordshire. As I said, our population is only 139,000.
Benefits must flow from a larger authority. A new authority would be able to provide more specialised services, equipment and staff. A larger authority can provide a greater range of technical services. It can also buy in bulk. Then there are the common services, such as direct labour, pooling of transport, and printing. All these could reduce our administrative costs. A larger and wealthier authority can give a greater range of services and, above all, greater flexibility in finance. In the end it comes back to finance and how big the county is.
I am surprised at the attitude of the hon. Member for Bromsgrove towards Lord Redcliffe-Maud's Report. Herefordshire would have been far worse off; it would have been a single unitary authority without a second tier. This is the report that the Labour Party was to implement if it had won the last election. I should add that not a single council in Herefordshire was in favour of the Maud Report.
This Bill will give greater strength to the district councils. It will give them
more power and representation. The hon. Member for Bromsgrove should not use all his efforts, as he has in the last few months, to try to block this merger which many people already consider is a fait accompli. We who believe that Herefordshire has a great future—I hope the hon. Gentleman also believes it has a great future—should be using every sinew and muscle in striving to get the new structure of local government right rather than to block it.
We should be sending recommendations to the Boundary Commission on how this large and sparsely populated county should be divided into district councils. To my amazement, the Boundary Commission has suggested that Herefordshire should become one huge district council, with the exception of two areas in my constituency—Ledbury and Bromyard. In everyone's opinion, including NALGO, this is far too large an area. It covers 427,000 acres and has a population of 118,000. Anyhow it is well above the Government's preferred population range. It would also mean that Herefordshire would not have adequate local government representation.
The ideal would be for Herefordshire to have three district councils. The City of Hereford is an historic and famous city with a population of 46,500. Here we have a special case. If Worcester City is to be an authority on its own—it certainly should be—then so should Hereford. That would be Central Hereford. North Hereford would be based on Leominster, and South Hereford would be based on Ross on Wye. So we would have three district councils, each of which could have a population in excess of this "mystique" figure of 40,000. Therefore it would comply with the guidelines which the Government have given us.
If the Boundary Commission cannot see its way clear to recommending three, it must be put forward two district councils to my right hon. Friend. In the meantime, it is so vital to get this right that I hope that some members of the board of the Boundary Commission will come to the counties of Worcester and Hereford and consult at local level so that they can find out where the problems lie.
I have endeavoured to be constructive and put forward the facts as I know them as the Member for North Hereford. There is one more thing that I should like to add, and that is that in our opinion it is wrong to site the new headquarters at Nunnery Wood just outside Worcester City. Bromyard in Herefordshire is about the centre of Area 17, but Malvern in Worcestershire would be very much more acceptable to everyone in our county. I mention that as the type of problem that we should be striving to solve before next year, rather than wasting valuable time, energy and ratepayers' money in fighting a losing battle because, as I said at the beginning, in the long-term most sensible people will realise that the salvation of our county lies in an amalgamation.
I have continually referred to North Hereford. My views are in line with the view of my hon. Friend the Member for Hereford. We are both confident and sincerely believe that real benefit could flow from this amalgamation. The two counties would come together in a combined local government unit of sufficient size to realise the full potentialities of major services to our constituents in the years ahead.
For those reasons I ask hon. Members on both sides of the House not to support these Amendments.

I do not want to take up the time of the House for long. I had not intended to intervene, but there is one matter on which the views of the hon. Member for Leominster (Sir Clive Bossom) might be amplified, and if I can help in that I shall do so.
The hon. Gentleman was correct in saying that Herefordshire opposed the Maud proposals and the Labour Government's White Paper. The reason why it did so—the hon. Gentleman will no doubt correct me if I am wrong—was that it felt that under the Maud proposals it was liable to be dominated too much by Worcestershire. I think that that was the basic point.
And not get full representation. Under the Bill we shall get much better representation at local level. We should not have achieved that under the Maud proposals.

I agree about the district council as against the proposed parish council under the Maud proposals. Having said that, the hon. Gentleman is fair enough to concede that the Maud proposals provided for the unity of Herefordshire with about 40 per cent. of Worcestershire, so that in that partnership, while the county had a right to complain—I am not saying that it did not—the Worcestershire influence over Herefordshire would have been less than it is today. That is the first point.
It is always assumed that because Maud made certain proposals and because a White Paper followed they were immutable—that they were like the laws of the Medes and Persians and could never be altered. It was not so. There were many matters that obviously the House would have altered between White Paper and Bill. There was not even a First Reading of a Bill. No doubt, as a Bill had progressed there would have been alterations under the Labour Government, just as there have been alterations to this Bill as it has progressed. My hon. Friend the Member for Birmingham, Small Heath (Mr. Denis Howell), who was in the Department at that time, gave a strong clue about them in Committee on, I think 30th November when he said that the whole matter was under discussion at that time.
10.0 a.m.
This is not to destroy the hon. Gentleman's argument. I do not want to do that. I merely want to put the record straight. I do not know that it has great relevance to the present situation, but the record might as well be as straight as it can be set.

I want to say only a few words, representing, as I do, an area of South Shropshire which borders on Herefordshire. I do this particularly as one of my two hon. Friends who represent the county is prevented from taking part in the debate because of his position in the Government.
We all appreciated the good faith of the hon. Member for Bromsgrove (Mr. Terry Davis). Nevertheless, from my personal experience I question one or two of the things he said. The hon. Gentleman laid great emphasis on the Malvern Hills. The area I represent, which is immediately north of Herefordshire,
greatly resembles Herefordshire in character. We have an east to west approach in Shropshire, which makes us the equivalent of what Hereford plus Worcester will be.
Going eastwards in my constituency one encounters, not the obstacle of the Malvern Hills, but the much more formidable obstacle of the Clee Hills. To the west of that, there is an area which is as rural and little populated as anything in Herefordshire. To the east there is one of England's developing industrial areas.
I agree with what was said so forcibly by my hon. Friend the Member for Leominster (Sir Clive Bossom). There is advantage in having a combination of these areas under one authority. It gives Shropshire a population. It gives us industry. It gives a variety of employment and opportunity which otherwise we would not have.
Unkind words have been said also about the problems of Powys. My hon. Friend the Member for Hereford (Mr. Gibson-Watt) has been much attacked about this, on the ground that Powys is an area even more sparsely populated than Hereford. We have this precise problem in South Shropshire. We have it, not at the first-tier level which we are discussing here, but at the second-tier level. We are having to face the precise problem—we shall want the help of my right hon. Friend the Secretary of State in solving it—that Hereford has had to face, namely: in the interests of conserving historic areas, does one take the risks that are involved now in keeping an area small in terms of population?
This is a real problem, because what has forced this situation on Governments—not only on this Government, but also on their predecessor, because, if anything, the Maud Report is more extreme than what is proposed now—is the realisation that the people can have the services they want only by having areas with populations of sufficient size.
Nobody appreciates more bitterly than a crusty old Tory like myself the resentments which must be encountered, particularly from those in authority such as councillors, when changes are proposed to the existing order of things. Nobody appreciates more than I do the natural ease with which people sign petitions.
They cannot be blamed; it is a matter of judgment by those who are in governmental positions and who have access to all the information that is available as to what ultimately is to be for the benefit of the people.
I should like it to be known by the people of Hereford—I speak from a long personal experience—that they could not be represented by two more completely dedicated Members than my hon. Friends the Members for Hereford and for Leominster. I can say this with sincerity and a special sense of gratitude because, before I was elected for Ludlow, we had a long interval in Ludlow and my constituents then had the services of those two hon. Members, who looked after the interests of Shropshire as well as those of Hereford. I do not think that every hon. Member would have sacrificed the time and trouble to the extent that my hon. Friends did.
This has obviously been a matter of judgment and no one has taken more trouble about it than they did. My hon. Friend the Member for Hereford has been in the invidious position of holding a post in the Government. If, having formed a judgment, he had decided that the Government's proposals were not in the interests of his people there was one thing he could have done; he could have resigned. But he has not resigned and that is because he genuinely believes that the proposals are correct.
I hope the message will go out, therefore, to the people of Hereford that they are represented here by two men of honour and that they are doing what they are doing because they believe it to be in the interests of the country, not merely for the present but in the future. I believe that in a few years from now their constituents will unite in the realisation that they should be grateful for the firm stand taken by my hon. Friends during those difficult months.

I start by following the remarks by my hon. Friend the Member for Ludlow (Mr. More). No matter what view any of us may have on this question, we all know as politicians that it would have been the easiest thing for my hon. Friend the Member for Leominster (Sir Clive Bossom) and my hon. Friend the Member for Hereford (Mr. Gibson-Watt) to join in what was
obviously a popular campaign in the county they represent, and to make great and immediate personal political capital out of it. Neither of them did. They have both taken an immense amount of care to be in close consultation with their councils and the publicat large. They have held meetings and they have put forward their view in an objective way because, on considering all the factors, they both believed that the proposals were in the long-term interest of their county. I believe that in public life if people are prepared to put up with a lot of present political unpopularity to achieve something they feel will benefit their area in the long term it is something we should appreciate. My two hon. Friends have done that.
I find it very surprising for an Amendment such as this to come from the Opposition in view of the policy which they advocated in office. It is no good the right hon. Member for Deptford (Mr. John Silkin) saying that they did not get to the stage of putting it into a Bill. They published the Maud Report, they considered the matter as a Government and they then published a very definite White Paper. They went into the last General Election quite clearly stating in their manifesto that they would reform local government along the lines of the White Paper. Nothing could have been more unpopular to the people of Hereford than the proposals in that White Paper. It is surprising therefore that they have tabled their Amendment when they categorically put forward proposals which would not just have eliminated Hereford as a separate county but would have left Herefordshire without any district council whatever. There would have been one council, probably based on Worcester or somewhere like that, and that would have been the only form of local government available to the people of Herefordshire.
Therefore to find an Amendment on the Order Paper put down by a group of Labour Members from the Midlands and Birmingham suggesting that they would like Herefordshire to be a separate county is a very remarkable change.

The Secretary of State is on a very fair point. Obviously if one is intending to do something one must examine what a political party has said in the past. But will he direct his mind to this point? I am also trying to
be fair. The Opposition have the duty of taking what we regard as a bad Bill and trying to make it workable within the framework set, not by the Opposition, but by the Government. If within that framework we have come to this conclusion, quite genuinely, as my hon. Friend the Member for Bromsgrove (Mr. Terry Davis) did, I cannot see why it lies in the Secretary of State's mouth to criticise us.

The reason is that the basis on which the right hon. Gentleman and his hon. Friends supported the unitary system—[Interruption.]—I hope the right hon. Gentleman will listen to the argument. The reason why they originally supported the unitary principle, and presumably still do support it, as the Opposition have stated quite clearly in the debates on the Bill, is that they consider there is an advantage in size, particularly for certain major services. They do not disagree with us on this. Their argument on education is that it should be with the metropolitan areas and not the districts. They see great advantages there for education, social services, broad transportation matters and strategic land use studies. There has never been any argument from the Opposition that they want smaller councils for those functions.
Therefore it is surprising to find in this case a group of Labour Members putting their names to an Amendment the object of which is to leave Herefordshire, with a population of 138,000, to provide those services. One of the Liberal Members—who have played such an active part in the debates throughout the night—also duly jumped on the band wagon, knowing the general feelings in Herefordshire, and joined in with Amendments saying that it should be left as a separate county.
It was particularly surprising coming from the hon. Member for Bromsgrove (Mr. Terry Davis), because no one was more relieved by the change in proposals for local government reform than the majority of his constituents.

I direct the right hon. Gentleman's attention to what my hon. Friend the Member for Birmingham, Small Heath (Mr. Denis Howell) said in Committee after I had made a speech about this very question of North Worcestershire and the change, which I
welcomed, when I said that I would have disagreed with this transfer. Indeed, the hon. Member for Meriden (Mr. Speed) later congratulated me on my advocacy concerning the boundaries of North Worcestershire.

I am not failing to congratulate the hon. Gentleman on his advocacy. All I know is that before the General Election the Labour proposals on local government reform were very much to the detriment of the people of Bromsgrove, Kidderminster and many parts of Worcestershire. They all very much appreciate the change that has taken place with regard to the new county.
The suggestion that there is a great division as a result of the Malvern Hills was dealt with very effectively by my hon. Friend the Member for Ludlow. As someone who most weekends walks the Malvern Hills, with one half of the walk in Herefordshire and the other halfin Worcestershire, I know that the top of the hill is the division between the two counties, and I know the speed and relative ease with which one can go from one to the other. The two collaborate in many functions, and there are many friendships between people in the two counties. The Three Choirs Festival and the Three Shires Show have for long been based on considerable unity between the two counties. I believe that it will be a county with many characteristics that the people of Worcestershire and Herefordshire hold in very high esteem and that it will give the people of Herefordshire a far better base on which to cope with the problems of the future.
10.15 a.m.
One admires a small county, in terms of population, that wishes to continue its separate existence. All Members of Parliament admired for a long time the battle Rutland put up, against all logic, for the retention of the county council. Such a fight is always held in high esteem. But with the type of problem that will arise and the scope of the services required in education and social services alone, it means that a county of this size experiences great disadvantages.
It has been pointed out that the neighbouring county in Wales has an even smaller population. Why should that count? With a smaller population that
neighbouring county in Wales is not only larger than Herefordshire or Worcester but it is twice as big as the new county we are proposing of Hereford and Worcester. It is only because of the remarkable sparsity of population and the fact that if one joined it to any other county to try to increase that population the size would become so massive and impossible that reluctantly one has to see a county like that suffer from the considerable problems it will incur because of having such a small rateable value and a small population. There is no need for Herefordshire to endure that suffering.
As to the view that the county might be dominated by Worcestershire, the answer was given in two arguments brought forward in this debate, one by my hon. Friend the Member for Leominster, who argued that the many mutual interests of people in Worcester and Hereford, the mutual interests of the rural populations of both counties, will ally people in the council chamber.
The argument against was very well expressed by the hon. Member for Bromsgrove. He said that neither Worcestershire County nor Worcester City had said they desperately wanted to have
Amendment made, No. 914, in page 201, leave out lines 3 to 8.—[Mr. Speed.]

Herefordshire. They look upon Herefordshire's coming into the new county as a matter of territorial gain or in terms of the power they would have over that county. They have looked on it as being of advantage to Herefordshire. Such an arrangement would be of more financial advantage to Herefordshire than to Worcestershire. They have looked upon it as a genuine partnership. I am certain that discussions will take place before the new elections. The councils elected after those elections will collaborate and co-operate to ensure that this is one of the finest counties in England. A county that can have the sporting double of Hereford United at football and Worcestershire County cricket team has in any case remarkable advantages.

On every possible ground of planning, transportation, better education, social service facilities, there is a very powerful argument for this new county. It is more powerful for the people of Herefordshire than any other section.
Question put, That the Amendment be made:—
The House divided: Ayes 11, Noes 57.

I beg to move Amendment No. 82, in page 201, column 2, leave out lines 38 to 41 and insert: 'Belton, Bradwell, Burgh Castle, Fritton and Hopton-on-Sea, somuch of the parish of Herringfleet as lies north of the boundary referred to in paragraph 5C of Part III of this Schedule and so much of the parish of Corton as lies north of the boundary referred to in paragraph 5D of that Part'.
With this Amendment it will be convenient to discuss the Amendments Nos. 119, 120 and 129.
No. 119, in page 204, line 34, at end insert: (i) the part of the existing parish of Corton in Suffolk.
No. 120, in page 204, line 37, at end insert: (l) the part of the existing parish of Herringfleet in Suffolk.
No. 129, in page 205, line 10, at end insert: (4) The part of the existing parish of Herringfleet in Norfolk shall be added to the parish of Fritton.

During the Committee stage an Amendment moved by my hon. Friend the Member for Yarmouth (Mr. Fell) was made which moved to Norfolk the five northernmost parishes of Lothingland rural district. This was justified because the parishes are immediately adjacent to Great Yarmouth. However, for the parish of Herringfleet, the boundary proposed in the Amendment in Committee needs some tidying up because it divided the village of St. Olave's on the line of the A406.
The Amendments improve the boundary by rewording the Amendment and by taking the whole of the village of St. Olave's into Norfolk. They add the northern part of the existing parish of Herringfleet to the parish of Fritton and constitute the remainder, in Suffolk, as a new parish.
Amendment No. 1039 gives a line slightly different from that in the original Government Amendment No. 110, so as to bring "Weasel Score" and half a dozen houses into Norfolk. This was done at the request of Herringfleet Parish Meeting and with the agreement of the authorities on both sides of the border.
My hon. Friend's Amendment overlooked the fact that between the eastern
boundary of the parish of Hopton-on-Sea and the coast there is a very narrow strip, mostly occupied by sea defence works and with no population, of the parish of Corton. This is probably the result of coast erosion. The Amendment puts things right by adding that strip to Hopton-on-Sea, by extending the southern boundary of Hopton-on-Sea eastwards by about 100 yards. The strip is added to Hopton and the remainder of Corton continues as a parish in Suffolk.
Further Amendments made: No. 85, in page 201, line 44, column 2, leave out 'Durham and Teesside' and insert 'Cleveland and Durham'.—[Mr. Speed.]
No. 94, in page 202, column 2, leave out 'Tyneside' and insert 'Tyne and Wear'.
No. 1035, in page 202, line 50, column 2, leave out from 'Suffolk' to end of line 51.—[Mr. Graham Page.]
I beg to move Amendment No. 100, in page 203, line 3, leave out 'except the areas in West Sussex'.
With this Amendment we shall discuss the following, all standing in the name of the hon. Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair): No. 103, in page 203, leave out lines 27 to 32.
No. 111, in page 204, line 18, leave out paragraph 6.
