We have had a very long night and the House is, understandably, very thin. It is sad that an issue which affects the wishes of a whole county should be debated before such a sparse House, when many hon. Members have had to depart for engagements in their constituencies or elsewhere.
The Bill at present provides for the transfer to West Sussex from Surrey of the greater part of the parishes of Horley and Charlwood, an area containing some 18,000 population but including also, within the affected part of Charlwood, the major airport known as London/Gatwick.
My Amendment seeks to maintain unaltered the present Surrey-West Sussex boundary in the area of Gatwick Airport.
I seek to show three things—first, that there is no good planning reason for making the change; secondly, that the people in the area affected are very strongly opposed to the move; thirdly, that the whole of Surrey is against this further important encroachment into the county from the south, having in 1963 under the London Government Act lost a great deal of its population and its rateable value.
I shall ask my right hon. Friend, in view of these arguments, to leave things as they are at least for 10 years. I shall ask him to defer a decision on this boundary, leaving it to the Boundary Commission being set up under the Bill. If he cannot meet us in this way, my intention would be to invite my hon. Friends to show Surrey's opposition by their votes in the Lobby.
Neither I nor any other Surrey Member served on Standing Committee D, but Amendments in similar terms to these were kindly moved on behalf of myself and other Surrey Members, and we are most grateful to those hon. Members who studied our case, took it up and presented it so well in the Committee.
When the then Under-Secretary of State for the Environment replied to the debate in the Committee, we heard for the first time the reason by which the Government sought to justify the proposed transfer. At the end of that debate, the Amendments were withdrawn so that between then and Report stage full consideration should be given to the Government's arguments. So much for that stage. Let me for a moment refer to the Government's policy statement on the Bill which I believe are being disregarded in this proposal.
Addressing the Conservative Party Conference in 1971, my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister said: We are determined to maintain so far as possible the deep rooted loyalties on which our local government was founded in the past…no-one in their right senses is in favour of change for change's sake. The White Paper itself, in paragraph 29, stated: Where possible existing county boundaries will be retained in order to keep the maximum existing loyalties and to minimise the administrative problems.
Clearly, the onus lies on those who are proposing a change in local government to demonstrate an overwhelming case. What, then, was the justification which the Under-Secretary of State put forward for this proposal in Committee?
First, my hon. Friend referred to the fact that the Redcliffe-Maud Commission had placed emphasis on the link between Gatwick and Crawley. Certainly, the Commission said that there were close links, particularly for employment, between Crawley on the one hand and Gatwick and the adjoining related area of Horley on the other. Indeed, the Commission proposed that Crawley should be added to Surrey. The Government's proposal is the reverse. Studies carried out by Surrey Council Council confirm the view of Redcliffe-Maud that there are strong economic and social links between the Gatwick area and Crawley, but also show very strong links between the Gatwick area and the Surrey districts to the north, notably Reigate Borough.
Redcliffe-Maud also considered that the links between the two sides of the Hampshire-Surrey border—the Black-water Valley area—were very strong and proposed that north-east Hampshire should be added to Surrey. At first, the Government adopted this suggestion but after strong objections from Hampshire decided to retain the present Surrey-Hampshire border unchanged. Surrey makes no objection to that.
The second point which my hon. Friend made in Committee was that Gatwick was linked with Crawley and the area to the south of Crawley in a major growth area proposal in the Strategic Plan for the South-East—Area 6. But at the time of the plan's publication, Gatwick was expected to become a two-runway airport and to expand vastly and rapidly. The more recent decision, which we welcome, to confine Gatwick to one runway has transformed the whole situation and the whole problem.
The present projection by the county council is that Surrey will be able to provide for up to half the airport's employment growth until Foulness becomes operational and pressure on Gatwick is relieved. The Crawley-Burgess Hill growth area is a major growth area in its own right in the general strategy of providing for the expanding population
of South-East England as a whole. It is only secondarily related to the airport. There is no question of the growth area strategy being adversely affected if the present boundary remains unchanged. Surrey and the two counties of West and East Sussex are well-advanced in preparing a sub-regional plan. Moreover, it appears to be agreed with the Department, as also for the growth area on the Surrey-Hampshire-Berkshire borders, that structure plans separately submitted by each county within the sub-regional framework can best give effect to the proposals. In short, the planning will be done just as effectively if the boundary is left as it is.
The third and final reason adduced by my hon. Friend the then Under-Secretary of State was the fact that Crawley is the largest urban area close to the airport. On that I would say only that the Reigate-Horley urban complex to the north of the airport has the capacity to increase by 1981 to 109,000 compared with what is believed to be the expected growth of Crawley to 90,000.
I submit that, far from there being a strong case for transfer, the overwhelming planning argument is the other way—namely, that Gatwick is a London-orientated airport with its major consequences affecting Surrey, since 80 per cent. of its passengers come from north of the airport via Surrey, its flight paths are east and west over Surrey, and the noise effects both near the airport and beneath the air routes are primarily felt by Surrey residents. Projects for ancillary facilities such as hotels, parking, industries serving the airport, and so on, will normally arise on the Surrey side along the lines of communication, notably within reach of the new motorways which are to be London-orientated and will link Gatwick with Heathrow. Moreover, the whole of the Gatwick area drains into the River Mole, which flows through Surrey to the Thames. This means that Surrey will have to cope with the serious drainage and sewage problems from the Gatwick area.
But this strong planning case against change is only half the story. It is powerfully reinformed by the overwhelming desire of the local people in Horley and Charlwood to stay in Surrey, together with the airport. Eighty-seven per cent.
of those eligible on the electoral roll signed a petition to that effect, and I had the pleasure of personally presenting it to my right hon. Friend the Minister for Local Government and Development in charge of the Bill. I must thank him for his great courtesy and patience in receiving representations and delegations—on which my fellow Members from Surrey constituencies accompanied me—not only from my constituency but from the whole of Surrey.
In replying to the debate in Committee, the Under-Secretary of State made an offer to the two parish councils that they might stay in Surrey even though the airport were to be transferred. This was a very harsh option to put before them—almost, "Do you wish to be hanged or shot?" At a widely advertised parish meeting in Horley, it was decided by 600 votes to 10 that the people wished the whole of the area, including the airport to stay in Surrey. This amounted to a refusal to exercise the choice offered because they saw no valid reason for the transfer of the airport and they hoped that the Government would withdraw this proposal.
Charlwood Parish Council took a slightly different line. It deferred holding such a meeting in the absence of knowledge as to the exact boundaries of the airport which would be moved into West Sussex, but there is no doubt that a Charlwood parish meeting would have come to the same conclusion as Horley. The Minister subsequently confirmed to the Charlwood Parish Council that the option would remain open even after the Bill had been passed. I hope that the Minister will be able to confirm that the option will remain open also to the affected parts of the Horley parish if, despite all the representations, the Government decide to persist in transferring the airport.
All these people care passionately about this issue. They have demonstrated at packed public meetings. They have blocked main roads. They have carried placards. They have marched to Whitehall. Horley and Charlwood have made it clear that they wish to continue being associated with the Surrey areas to the north with which they have long-established social and traditional ties. In addition, the case of the local people
and the county case on planning have received massive support from the rest of Surrey, acting through a committee representative of the county council. I hope that my hon. Friend the Member for Chertsey (Mr. Grylls), whose constituency is on the other side of the county from Gatwick, will, if he is fortunate enough to catch your eye, Mr. Deputy Speaker, enlarge on this point and show Surrey's determination not to have further encroachments on its area from the south.
This boundary change is not proposed by the Government because of any major matter of principle on local government reform as stated in the White Paper. For example, town and country are closely intermingled in the wider area around Gatwick and will continue to be where-ever the boundary is drawn. Moreover, it is common ground that the situation around Greater London is unique in the country from the point of view of the relation of town and country, of communications and of other planning matters. There is a strong reason for creating and maintaining powerful authorities around London's edge …as a counterweight to the enormous power of the Greater London Council", as was stated by Sir Jack Longland in a minority Royal Commission Report.
10.45 a.m.
Against this background, it would be wrong further to reduce the size of Surrey, bearing in mind that it has already suffered substantial loss. Around Gatwick, the pattern of development, communications and social life is extremely complex. The influence of Gatwick is widespread and it is felt over a substantial area of East Surrey. It is quite impossible, by any boundary change, to place within the one county both the airport and the sphere of its influence. Indeed, the study area for the current planning work being undertaken jointly by East and West Sussex and Surrey extends from Burgess Heath and Hay-wards Heath in the south, to Dorking, Reigate and Oxted in the north, thus encompassing a large area of Surrey as well as of the two Sussexes.
The interdependence of this wider area was recognised by the South-East Economic Planning Council, which was unable to make any logical or reasonable
suggestions for boundary adjustments when giving its view on the Commission's proposals to the Government. Thus when one examines the situation at Gatwick in the context of county boundaries in the South-East, it becomes apparent that the planning arguments on which the Government base their case for change are unsound. The growth area and the surrounding inter-related sphere of influence cannot possibly be placed in one county, nor will the Government's proposed change achieve this objective. In that event, it is surely much better to leave the area divided between two counties along a reasonably straight boundary which has existed for many years and which does not cut through the airport or any built-up area.
Moreover, the present boundary runs through an area of green belt land between the airport and Crawley which, as a result of deliberate planning policy supported by successive Governments, has been kept open and undeveloped. We should keep to this boundary. In this way we can ensure that the two future counties of Surrey and West Sussex will continue planning the whole area of Gatwick, Crawley and its surrounding hinterland in a close and fruitful partnership, as indeed now exists through the Joint Advisory Committee set up early in 1971. We see no reason why the collaboration required between counties which, on reflection and after pressure, the Government accepted for Area 6—the Black-water area—on the western border of Surrey should not be accepted also for Area 6 on the southern border on the basis of the existing county boundary.
To sum up, there is a very strong planning case for retaining the airport in Surrey, powerfully reinforced by the local people's desire to remain within the county. Even if the Government felt that the arguments were finely balanced, we say to the Minister that the benefit of the doubt should be given to the county in which the area is at present situated in accordance with the philosophy of the White Paper of maintaing existing loyalties and avoiding change for change's sake.
We accordingly ask the Government to take the view that in all the circumstances the right and proper course would be to make no change in the Surrey-West Sussex boundary at this juncture
but to leave the matter over for full consideration by the Local Government Boundary Commission when it carries out its general review of county boundaries in 10 or so years' time and when the situation regarding Gatwick is clearer.
I hope very much that the Minister will feel able to indicate his acceptance of this Amendment in the knowledge and understanding that the Government of the day will have full opportunity in 10 years' time of giving further and full consideration to the whole of the problem in the light of the considered advice of the commission and when the rôle of Gatwick Airport in relation to Foulness Airport will be clearer. However, if the Minister cannot meet us, I must make it clear that the people of Surrey have demanded that we make it clear beyond any peradventure that we challenge in this House, this measure of the Government, and we shall pursue it into another place if, sadly, that should become necessary.

Having listened to my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair) and having heard a good deal of what Surrey people have said on this issue, I, like the West Sussex County Council, am very well aware of the depth of local feeling which has been aroused in Surrey over the Government's proposals. One is almost led to think that the prospect of the West Sussex County Council forming the administration for what is now part of Surrey is regarded by Surrey as being an encroachment of a tyrannical and despotic administration against which the barricades must be drawn up. I had not previously thought of Dorking being in any sense a no-go area, but these days one cannot be too sure. However, it is time that the case for the Government's proposals should be made and I shall hope to deal with some of my hon. Friend's points during my remarks.
It is certainly true that the response to the petition was a massive one by any standards. I think, though, it would have been slightly happier if the petition itself had not been endorsed in certain cases—even though I fully accept that in the great majority of cases it was an absolutely genuine expression of feeling—in such a way, of which I have direct evidence in at least one case, that the
top of the petition was folded over and these lines appeared:
"1. Do you want to see your rates increased?
2. Do you want more aircraft noise?
3. Do you want to see Surrey desolated?" I am bound to say that if I happened to live in that locality I should be running very fast to sign that petition, but I fully concede that this was a genuine feeling of the people of Surrey and that this is what they meant the Government should hear. However, I do not believe that the full story has been set out and I think it right that the Government's proposal should be set out in a somewhat different light.
As my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking said, of course the story goes a good deal deeper than plain sentiment. It has existed since the strategic plan for the South-East was drawn up and supported by the Regional Economic Planning Council. As the House knows, the strategic plan itself has now been supported by the Government, and so far as the South-East is concerned, Area 6 comprises Crawley, Burgess Hill and Gatwick. It has always seemed sensible that the area should be administered by one authority, but, of course, much more important than that, the size of the growth area and the significance of the increase in the population has long been apparent to the East and West Sussex County Councils, and, of course, to the Surrey County Council itself. That is why, as my hon. Friend says, all three counties have been working together for a long time to see how development in the totally new area could best proceed.
This is the point I must stress at the outset, that Surrey County Council has long been fully engaged and wholly involved in the joint advisory committee of the three county councils. It was set up for this purpose. Surrey County Council has known all along, and, indeed, has helped to work it, and agreed to the estimates which have been made about the expansion of the area as a whole and of Gatwick in particular. That county council has been deeply involved in the whole process of estimating both growth and the planning consequences of it. The figures which I have are those which have been agreed by the advisory committee, of which Surrey County Council has formed part, and on which Surrey
members have helped over some time to draw up.
One estimate is that of the total growth of population by 1981, and, within that total, the estimate of the growth of Gatwick itself. The estimate in the original strategic plan was that the whole population of the growth area would be increased by 80,000 by 1981, but the advisory committee, including Surrey, advised in a report dated 18th April this year, and in a more recent Press release jointly issued by all three county councils and dated 5th May, that the assessment of population growth needed to meet the labour demand in this growth area by 1981 was 120,000. The report to which I have referred mentioned that the annual rate of population growth to meet this figure up to 1981 had been accepted by all three planning authorities, including, of course, Surrey. But what concerns Surrey——

My hon. Friend and I have argued this point before. I wonder whether the basis of that calculation preceded the decision on Foulness, which has basically changed the whole calculation for new employment in the area.

No. My hon. Friend is not right in that assumption because the Press release to which I have referred, given by the three county councils, was dated 5th May this year, so that they were well aware of the third London airport.
What concerns Surrey is the growth of Gatwick itself. This is also in the report to which I have referred. It is to be found in Table I on page 2. Item 3 lists specifically the growth to 1981 associated with a one-runway airport—not a two-runway airport, but a one-runway airport. The figure accepted by Surrey is that the population growth would be 42,000 between 1966 and 1981. Since 1966, of course, the number employed at Gatwick has increased from 5,000 to 8,500, but the estimate of the number to be employed at Gatwick in 1981 has also been increased by the Airports Authority from 14,000 to 17,000. The total population increase as a result of Gatwick's expansion is still expected to be some 42,000. Again, this figure is recognised by Surrey. It has been suggested, though not by my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking, that employment at Gatwick may decline
after the third London airport comes into being. Of course, this point is one which can readily be checked, and I must tell the House that I have checked this matter with the Airports Authority, which has informed me that up to 1986 and beyond it can see no reason for the labour force at Gatwick declining at all. Indeed, if anything, it would expect it to increase.
11.0 a.m.
We know that Surrey has accepted that the population, as a result of Gatwick's growth, will expand by 42,000 by 1981. The question is: where are these people to go? Of course, they will have to go, very largely, to West Sussex. From the same report, drawn up with the assistance of Surrey, the only allocation made provisionally to Surrey and approved by them was 13,000 out of a total expected increase in the area as a whole of 120,000 by 1981. That 13,000 was at Horley.
The Press release of 5th May also mentioned that at Horley there were still problems to be resolved about drainage and aircraft noise, so that it is by no means certain that Horley can take them. But even if we take 13,000 as the figure, they are not, of course, specially related to the growth of Gatwick itself. This is natural growth to which we are referring. The Surrey County Council has never said that it would specially earmark this development for 13,000 just for Gatwick. If they did, what would happen to Surrey's own natural growth?
All these reports from the Advisory Committee have had to be agreed. The report to which I have referred, that of 18th April, was accepted by the four Surrey Members present. The three planning authorities also accepted it. On their own admission, Surrey, have acknowledged that they can fill only a small fraction of the 42,000 growth from Gatwick alone by 1981. Yet they want to keep the rates from Gatwick. It is a manifestly unfair and unjust proposition, and their own figures prove this to be the case.
All this, of course, refers to the position in 1981. But it is plainly unfair now that West Sussex does not get the rates from Gatwick. Of those employed at Gatwick, there are far more living in Crawley in my constituency than in the whole of Surrey, and nearly three times as many as live in Horley. Why should
Surrey enjoy the rates from Gatwick when most of the people who work there live in West Sussex? There is a very close identity of interest between Gatwick and Crawley. A large part of the reason for Crawley's growth—it is now well over 70,000 and is due to increase to 110,000—has been its close association with Gatwick.
My hon. Friend said that there are far more people living in Crawley who work at Gatwick. Does he know what the figures are?
Yes, though the figures which I have are somewhat out of date. They are the 1966 figures. They come from the 1966 census——
They are the latest available?

Yes, they are the latest available. Of a total at that time of 4,420 employed, 2,280 lived in Sussex, of whom 1,640 lived in Crawley; 630 lived in Horley and 750 elsewhere in Surrey. Far more live in Crawley than in the whole of the rest of Surrey.
Both Governments have accepted the principle that Gatwick and Crawley must go together. Indeed, the right hon. Member for Deptford (Mr. John Silkin) confirmed this during the Committee stage of the Bill. He said on 27th January: I am bound to say that I thought that the Under-Secretary of State made the slightly stronger case for putting the areas together. I listened very carefully to both of them; I do not think that there is any doubt that they must be kept together, and, frankly, it follows that Crawley must go into West Sussex."—[Official Report, Standing Committee D, 27th January, 1972; c. 1030.] As Crawley has been in West Sussex for a long time, I assume that he meant that Gatwick must go into West Sussex. I look forward to having his support in the Division later.
The probability is that the hon. Gentleman will not have my support. Mature reflection always sharpens the mind.

I dare say that mature reflection after a long night has had that effect.
There are very close links between Horley and Crawley as well. Crawley
College of Technology has 165 students from Horley. They use the schools, the Crawley Swimming Pool, the sports arena, and 400 Surrey residents use the library. They naturally look to Crawley as the nearest large shopping town, and commercial interests in Crawley estimate that between 5 per cent. and 10 per cent. of their turnover is attributable to spending by Charlwood and Horley residents. With respect to my hon. Friend, I do not think that the argument that Gat-wick's links are with Surrey can be sustained.
It is true, of course, that Surrey knows a good deal about aircraft noise. But so also does West Sussex because both counties use the same consultants and share the costs. There are certainly more people in West Sussex affected by aircraft noise than there are in Surrey. This is a straight conflict of fact between my hon. Friend and myself, but my information and advice is that there are many more people affected by aircraft noise in West Sussex than there are in Surrey. Certainly they are every bit as well organised and vociferous in West Sussex as they are in Surrey.
West Sussex has plainly shown its competence in handling a large and rapidly expanding area in Crawley, and it will, in fact, be responsible for the growth and development of this whole area. Surrey, on the other hand, cannot expand because of the Green Belt and because of the drainage problems of the River Mole, to which my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking has already referred. By their own figures they have shown that they cannot manage to house more than a small proportion of Gatwick's expansion, and for that reason it is elementary justice that Gatwick, Horley and Charlwood should go into West Sussex. That is the only fair and reasonable solution.

I support my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair). I congratulate him on the work that he has done in this matter and on the clear way in which he has advanced his case.
I do not intend to repeat all the arguments. I merely wish to underline my support for the Amendment. May I say to my hon. Friend the Member for Horsham (Mr. Hordern) that there is
no question of the Surrey people looking on the Sussex administrators as ogres or fiends with whom they would not be associated in any circumstances. As he said, the counties are working well together and I am sure that the people as they pass over the boundaries in either direction to work will get on very well. According to the 1966 figures, more of them passed over the boundaries from Crawley to work in Surrey than the other way. This is according to Redcliffe-Maud.
As we know, local government changes provoke strong feelings. Perhaps they are not always directly logical but they are not necessarily wrong because of that. Local government affairs are not always run on logic. They are run by people, and there are very many factors at work which the planners do not often appreciate. As a result, I am sure that people are sometimes irritated. They use expressions like "parochial" and "parish pump" and all the rest; and indeed there is a certain amount of truth in that because that is what local government is. Of course, their feelings often run counter to the central planners who are looking at maps and drawing lines. But no one would suggest that it is not a good thing that there should be this strong local feeling. We often hear accusations of apathy at local government elections, but we find when serious changes are proposed that there is a great deal of interest in local affairs.
My first point, which my hon. Friend has already made, is that the people concerned in Surrey do not want this change. This applies throughout the county of Surrey as a whole. One reason is that Surrey is a particularly well run county. I do not say that because I am connected with Surrey. It is an admitted fact that Surrey is a well run county, and it has very good relations with its districts. That is one reason why the local people do not want to change.
It seems to me that, sometimes, when we reorganise local government, we go for the lowest common denominator. We find one part of the country where the system is not functioning, so we tear the whole system up by the roots all over the place in an effort to get it right, so that that one area will be right, although all the rest suffer. However, I shall not dwell on that any more.
The Government say that there is a strong planning case for the transfer of Gatwick to Sussex. The Redcliffe-Maud Report took the contrary view. Although we do not agree with the main principles of Redcliffe-Maud—I certainly do not—no one denies that the Commission investigated the whole matter, both generally and in detail, and certainly on detail we must respect its views.
Although the Government say that there is a strong planning case to transfer Gatwick to Sussex, Redcliffe-Maud said quite the reverse, and this must at least raise doubt about whether the Government planners are right. I shall not quote what Redcliffe-Maud says, since I do not wish to take up time, but that point is clear.
The Government say also that Gatwick is linked to Crawley. That is an oversimplification of the matter. It is certainly linked to Surrey, for it is in Surrey. I do not attempt to assess which county is affected environmentally more than the other, but Gatwick certainly affects Surrey very much, and I incline to the view that the configuration of the airfield and the runway tends to affect Surrey a bit more, though perhaps not all that much.
Broadly, the argument as put by my hon. Friend the Member for Horsham is based on the major growth area of Crawley and south of Crawley. I do not know the geography or topography particularly well down there, but I understand that to be one of his arguments. Does he seriously suggest that that development will not take place if Gatwick stays out of Sussex? Does he think that major developments there will be held up or not take place on that account? Does he think that Gatwick with one runway is really the deciding factor?

No, I am certain that the development to the south will proceed. The question is whether, with the expansion of Gatwick, involving an increase in population of 42,000, who would very largely be housed south of Crawley, in West Sussex, the rates from Gatwick should go to West Sussex instead of to Surrey.

We are agreed, then, that the development would not be stopped if Gatwick stayed in Surrey. As
regards the rates, I have always been led to believe that it is the built-up areas which are the source of rateable value. West Sussex would have that, though I agree that, if Gatwick stayed in Surrey, it would not have the rates from there.
My hon. Friend the Member for Horsham produced some figures for 1966 of population employed in Gatwick and living either in and about Crawley or in Surrey. Frankly, there did not seem to me to be all that much difference. There were more in Sussex, but not so many more. Also, although he points out that there is green belt north of Gatwick, there is room for a good deal of development there. My hon. Friend the Member for Dorking gave the figures. All of us with green belt in our constituencies know of the enormous amount of house building which is done in the course of rounding off and filling in. In my constituency I am always astonished at how much is done. So I am certain that there will be housing development, and I do not accept that the disparity of population employed from one side or the other will be all that great.
11.15 a.m.
I put the matter to the Minister in this way. It can be argued closely one side or the other. I am sure, especially since there are two reports giving opposite decisions, that the Government must agree that the argument is not decisive either way. In that case, I argue that it is not wise to make the change, particularly when so many people in the area oppose it.
It will sever people's loyalties to their counties, which is something which we wish to preserve. Also, the position in the county as a whole has to be considered. My hon. Friend the Member for Dorking mentioned the London Government Act, with which I was particularly concerned. Surrey suffered considerable loss on that occasion. The county as a whole must be considered. One has only to look at the map to see that this is a bite into the narrowest part. Looking ten years ahead, if we are still here, we may well be arguing in much the same way that Surrey is to lose more.

I stress that the arguments are evenly balanced now. As my hon. Friend said, the Local Government Boundary Com-
mission will be looking at this matter in about ten years. Why not leave it until then? That will be the time to consider the matter. I hope that the Amendments will be accepted.

My hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair) made the case for Gatwick remaining in Surrey as well as it could possibly be made. He made it forcefully and, if I may say so, charmingly, just as we should expect him to do.
I am something of an intruder here, because I represent Lewes, the county town of Sussex, which is in East Sussex. We are on speaking terms with West Sussex, but no more so than we are with Surrey and Kent. In fact, we get on fine with all three of our neighbouring counties.
Coming from East Sussex, I have studied this question with great care and, I hope, without emotion or sentiment, and I have done my best to reach a judgment on the merits of the case. My judgment may be wrong, but I shall briefly put to the House the conclusion which I have reached, and why.
My conclusion is that Crawley and Gatwick, together with the parishes of Charlwood and Horley, march together. Especially in the light of modern developments, it is, in my view, a historical accident that Crawley happens to be in West Sussex and Gatwick happens to be in Surrey, with the county boundary separating the two. I come to the conclusion, therefore, that the Government's proposals are broadly right and should be accepted by both sides.
My basic reasons are simple. First, as I have said, Gatwick and Crawley are hard by each other; they march together. From the standpoint of community links, the arrow undoubtedly points towards West Sussex more than towards Surrey. My hon. Friend the Member for Horsham (Mr. Hordern) made that clear. He is absolutely right, and it has not been denied. The arrow will point increasingly towards West Sussex as further developments take place.
Nobody so far has mentioned education. The arguments in this respect are six of one and half a dozen of the other.
because at the moment county boundaries do not matter very much in education and they will not matter very much in future.
The technical arguments have been mentioned. I refer to whether Surrey or West Sussex has the necessary expertise. Too much can be made of this. I freely admit—I am glad to do so—that Surrey has done a first-class job about Gatwick and I am not in the least critical, but I am equally satisfied that if West Sussex had the responsibility, it would do an equally good job.
The most important argument is that mentioned by my hon. Friends speaking from opposite points of view. It is that Gatwick is at the northern end of a great growth area of considerable importance and running the whole way from Brighton through my constituency passing through Hurstpierpoint, Hassocks and Burgess Hill and then Crawley and on to Gatwick. It seems to be only sensible and sound planning for the whole of this area to be planned as one. It is part of the agreed South-East regional strategy.
It also seems only fair, to put it quite simply, that if what I have said is correct, the county that has responsibility for supervising this growth area and the heavy financial burden that goes with that should have the benefits of the rateable value of Gatwick.
Finally, I refer to a subject which several hon. Members mentioned, aircraft noise. We have to be careful not to draw too many planning conclusions from who is most disturbed by aircraft noise. I speak with first-hand knowledge as I live immediately below the main flight path to the east side of Gatwick. I live on the south edge of the Ashdown Forest at Chelwood Gate at the point where the aircraft are flying extremely low as they start to climb and turn, and there is nothing that I do not know about noise!
If noise is the criterion we should all be pleased if we could transfer Gatwick to East Sussex! We know all about noise in East Sussex. Aircraft fly over my house and then right over Lewes and Seaford. However, Gatwick cannot be given to East Sussex and I am not seriously suggesting that it should. But I am glad that
the report of the consultants appointed by the three counties, East Sussex, West Sussex and Surrey, is due shortly.I hope that they will go carefully into the future of Gatwick in this respect and that their proposals on the subject of the height of aircraft and flight paths may ensure that there is minimum disturbance.
I thought of moving a manuscript Amendment—if I had been allowed—proposing to close down Gatwick airport and open another airport in Yorkshire, where. I understand, such a development would be acceptable. This is a subject about which we all care whatever view we may take about which county should have control. We should all like to get rid of Gatwick, which is an ugly, noisy and smelly brute in a lovely countryside. I thank heaven that there are not two runways!
But Gatwick will not go away, and we have to live with it and we have to look after it. It seems to me that the Government have studied the matter impartially and with great care and that they have come to the right conclusion by deciding that Gatwick should now be within West Sussex.

I congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair) on his able exposition of the Surrey case. My constituency is not primarily concerned in this reorganisation, but I am a Surrey Member and I know from personal experience that people in Surrey feel strongly about what is to happen, and I hope to reflect some of those feelings this morning.
There are three aspects of the matter on which I can speak from some personal knowledge. First, my constituency was one of the constituencies into which encroachment was proposed in 1963 under the London Government Act. My constituency managed to beat off that encroachment, and it survived as part of Surrey. Only a few months ago, a second attack was made by the GLC, and again it was beaten off, thanks to my right hon. Friend. We are thus extremely sensitive about encroachments on our territory, and I think that that goes for the whole of Surrey. We are very near London and various bites have occurred and the natural instinct of Surrey is therefore to defend itself.
The River Mole runs through my constituency at the point where it joins the Thames. We were affected very badly by the disastrous floods of 1968 when many thousands of my constituents were made homeless and many homes were flooded. The Dittons and the Moleseys were seriously affected, and none of us wants a repetition of that. By that I mean that it is important for Surrey to control the whole of the course of the Mole, but particularly the headwaters, because there is a large area of runoff for the headwaters of the Mole, particularly from Gatwick Airport. We do not know to what extent this increased the flow, but it was increased, and it is important for the people of my constituency to know that the county council is controlling the course of the river.
Secondly, I speak from personal experience on the subject of aircraft noise, not at Gatwick but at London Airport itself. We all know what it means and we should all like the county to control the area where an airport is located. We all know that it is particularly important to keep control once obtained.
I am not qualified to speak on the planning grounds, but I echo what my hon. Friend said when he quoted the Minority Report of Sir Jack Longland of the Royal Commission when he said that it was important to planning for there to be large and powerful authorities surrounding the area of London as the GLC was such an enormous and powerful organisation itself. This is one of the reasons for keeping Surrey strong.
Finally, I hope that my right hon. Friend will be able to give us the benefit of the doubt, the words used in the White Paper, and do something helpful for Surrey and at least to give us 10 years as a cooling-off period while we await the outcome of the consideration of the Foulness project. If he feels unable to do that, I shall have to vote for the Amendment in view of the doubts which are felt in the county part of which I represent.

I want briefly to support the views so ably expressed by my hon. Friend the Member for Horsham (Mr. Hordern). As a Sussex Member, I thoroughly sym-
pathise with and understand the view expressed by my hon. Friend the Member for Esher (Mr. Mather). When boundary changes come up, there are inevitably strong feelings, particularly in an area into which there was encroachment in the early 1960s. The strength of feeling in Surrey must be understood, and I think that hon. Members from Sussex understand it.
One of the important reasons for reorganising boundaries is to create greater efficiency in planning and administration. It is on that argument that I believe this change needs to be made. The clear effect of the proximity of Crawley to Gatwick, their close links, which were backed up in the White Paper and by the South-Eastern Regional Planning Council, and the future growth potential of the area south of Crawley seem to be the key factors in planning for this area.
My hon. Friend the Member for Horsham quoted statistics based on the 1966 census. We were told that roughly 50 per cent. of the people who work at Gatwick live in Surrey and the other 50 per cent. in Sussex, of whom 1,640 live in Crawley itself. Clearly there is this vitally important link not only in housing, but in other ancillary services between Gatwick and Crawley.
However, there has been this other discussion about the future expansion of the airport during the 1970s which is very important. I understand the argument put forward by my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair) that, now that the decision has been taken that there will not be a second runway, we should perhaps reconsider this matter. All the evidence points to a dramatic increase in passenger and aircraft turnover at Gatwick with only one runway during the next 10 years. In fact, the British Airports Authority has already said that it estimates there will be about 5 million passengers this year and that conceivably by 1980 with only one runway there could be about 16 million passengers a year. Therefore, it is clear that there will be a dramatic expansion at the airport over the next 10 years.
My hon. Friend the Member for Horsham explained that the work force at the airport numbers about 8,500, and it is anticipated that it will double in the next 10 years. It is also anticipated that there
will be a demand for extra housing for up to 42,000 people.
So we come to the third factor—growth. Which of these areas would be likely to take the largest part of the increase in the population? The arguments have already been ably put. However, it is clear that the South-Eastern Strategic Plan indicates that one of the five main growth areas in the South-East will clearly be south of Crawley in that corridor down to Burgess Hill and Brighton. This is a key factor when considering the planning implications of Gatwick Airport.
If it is true that West Sussex will have to house the majority of those who will be working at the airport in future, then about two-thirds of the work force will be living in Sussex by the end of this decade. This is an important factor.
We then come back to the problem: who should carry the responsibility for Gatwick, a great international airport?
The criteria cannot just be a question of local tradition and sentiment. I suggest it must be based broadly on planning and administrative grounds. For that reason, the argument lies most strongly in favour of placing the airport under the control of West Sussex.
I have listened carefully to some of the arguments put forward by, for example, my hon. Friend the Member for Esher and I should like to comment briefly on three points.
First, my hon. Friend stressed that the airport seems to go to the North, because 80 per cent. of passengers who use the airport come from the North. This seems a totally irrelevant argument in deciding who should or should not control the airport. The key factor in deciding who should control the airport should be who provides the supporting services, the work force, the housing and ancillary services.
The second point concerned noise. This is an important argument but it is not just of importance for Surrey; it is equally important for Sussex. Therefore, we should not use this argument as the main criteria for determining who should control the airport.
The third point was that we should wait another 10 years before making any change. That would be absolutely and fundamentally wrong for the reason I have already given: that it is already
anticipated there will be a dramatic expansion in passenger and aircraft turnover at the airport, a great demand for housing by the increased population of up to 42,000 in the next 10 years, and that West Sussex will have to carry the can for that.
I do not think that West Sussex can be expected to cope with the consequences, which involve heavy expenditure, of having Gatwick Airport there without controlling the source of the problem, which includes planning control over Gatwick as well as the revenue. That would be manifestly wrong and unjust. Strong representations have been made to me by the local councils in my constituency that that would be wrong and would not be acceptable to the people of Sussex. Therefore, I strongly support the Government in their decision on planning and administrative grounds.

It is perhaps more in sorrow than in anger that I support the Amendments. I have always been an enthusiastic supporter of the reform of local government. I am glad my right hon. Friend the Secretary of State is here, because the Government are to be congratulated on entering into this major reform of the whole of local government in England. It is only Conservative Governments, in the 1963 Act and now in this Bill, who have been brave enough to do this important job. Therefore, to some extent one is sad that we are involved in this problem.
In a major reform of this kind it is inconceivable that there will not be a number of points of proposed change which various people believe are not right. Particularly if change affects a Member's constituency, he would be failing in his duty if he did not raise the matter in the House.
My hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair) brilliantly described in his speech the strong feeling in Surrey that this is a continuation of the erosion process on our borders. Although my constituency is at the opposite end of the county from Gatwick, I have been amazed over these last few months at the strength of feeling which this matter has evoked. It surprised me very much. It seemed almost as if all the cars in my constituency sprouted stickers overnight proclaiming, "Keep Gatwick in
Surrey". That vividly brings it home to one.
Surrey suffered under the London Government Act by the removal of 37 per cent. of its population. Surbiton, Merton, Richmond and Kingston-upon-Thames—particularly Kingston-upon-Thames, the very seat of our county government—were summarily taken out of the county. Therefore, this proposal will create a real feeling of annoyance and danger.
This new threat to our boundaries is felt very strongly by the electorate, the responsible local government councils, the parish councils and, perhaps most important of all, the women's institutes who have written to us on every conceivable occasion saying how cross they are about it. There is, as my hon. Friend said, a united feeling against and very strong opposition to this proposal.
My right hon. Friend the Secretary of State, in his original White Paper, said that we should not have change for the sake of change; we should have change only if it will make the situation better. Having listened to the debates today, as I have on other occasions when various planning arguments have been rehearsed, I find it difficult to be convinced that there is a sound, unanswerable planning reason for removing Gatwick from Surrey.
The geographical effects will be particularly damaging. If this proposal goes through, in future years the area will be known as the straits of Gatwick; it will be the throttling of a county; Surrey's neck will be wrung just as the neck of a chicken is wrung.
My hon. Friend the Member for Dorking propounded the planning argument. The contrary view was advanced by my hon. Friend the Member for Horsham (Mr. Hordern). To be convinced of the rightness of the decision, we must be satisfied that the planning arguments are sound. An ordinary person can listen to respectable people—professional people, particularly—putting opposing views and agree with both sides.
The planning arguments for this amputation are doubtful. I accept that there are some grounds, but they do not convince me. Because I believe in the
development of a major organisation such as an international airport, I must look at the strategic regional position. I had some experience of this when I was a member of the Greater County Council, which was a strategic authority responsible for the strategic planning of the whole Greater London area. An airport must fall within a strategic plan. It is difficult to convince people of the proposal merely by saying that it is based on Gatwick's being a southward or an eastward-looking airport.
The argument that a large proportion of the workers live in Crawley or other parts of Sussex is of little importance. A large percentage of my constituents live in Surrey and work in London or in Sussex. One aspect of modern life is that people drive a long way to work. People who have to go to work in the area of another local authority do not believe that something terrible is involved or that they must, for instance, produce a passport.
The Government White Paper touches on the regional aspects of reform but holds the matter in suspense for the Crowther Report. It will become clearer that the regional consideration makes the decision to have this in a tight planning concept rather old fashioned.
The reality is that both counties share the airport. They share the planning, the looking to the future, and the day-today responsibility in joint committees. As far as I know, this works adequately. There is no reason to parcel it up and move it off elsewhere.
It is worth saying on behalf of Surrey County Council that so efficiently has the airport been administered by Surrey—Sussex has taken part in a number of decisions, but under the aegis of Surrey—that many organisations responsible for foreign international airports are sent by the central Government to look at the airport. They would not come to Gatwick if it were a badly-run airport.
A number of administrative arguments are common to large airports. Heathrow is of great interest to my constituents because of the noise problem and also because of the terrible accident at Staines recently, which was dangerously close to my constituency. A few feet would have brought it my side of the river. That terrible accident was dealt with very
efficiently by the accident services which came from Surrey, Middlesex, and Greater London.
11.45 a.m.
Heathrow is divided between Greater London and Surrey. As far as I know, its accident services and its administration are perfectly efficient and have not caused any great difficulties.
I ask my right hon. Friend the Minister for Local Government and Development to suspend judgment on this problem until 1980. He will say that the Government's job is to make decisions, but they must make the right decisions. In this instance there is an overwhelming case for suspending judgment until we have seen the effect of the new airport at Foulness in the early 1980s. I suspect that the development of aviation and airport development will change greatly over the next 10–20years. Such developments as short take-off aircraft will make the over-expansion of Gatwick unnecessary and will greatly transform the situation. Gatwick may even be able to shrink and some of the beautiful surrounding countryside may be put to a different use.
I ask my right hon. Friend not to amputate this part of our county. It would be tragic and painful. For the reasons that my hon. Friends and I have advanced, it would be a wholly unnecessary piece of surgery. I implore the Government to accept the Amendment.

I ask my hon. Friend the Undersecretary to resist the Amendment, despite the effective and sincere speech of my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair).
I shall concentrate my remarks on the airport. The House may, rightly, ask why I, as the Member for Kemptown—in East Sussex—should have any interest in an airport some miles north of Brighton. I will explain why. My hon. Friend the Member for Dorking made great play of the fact that Gatwick Airport is London-oriented. That is largely true now, but more and more passengers who are flying out of Gatwick are coming from towns such as Brighton and other parts of the South East, I see a dramatic change occurring in the position of Gatwick as an airport in the South East not far in the future.
The new Maplin Sands Airport and Heathrow will together meet 90 per cent. of London's requirements. At the same time, with our entry into the Common Market the pressures upon the South East will grow and grow. Gatwick will become the European airport for the whole of the South East.
Brighton will be dramatically affected by our entry into the European Community, by an increased number of visitors to the town—not only holiday-makers, but those attending major conferences, particularly international conferences, an increasing number of which will be held at Brighton and other South-East resorts.
I see a situation arising in which Governments of whatever political complexion will face increasing pressure to allow Gatwick to continue to expand. At present it may have only one runway. In a few years the whole matter may well have to be reconsidered. Therefore, purely on the argument that Gatwick will alter its whole axis of operation to the South East and to Europe, there is an overwhelming case for the Government acting now and ensuring that Gatwick becomes part of the county of West Sussex.
We know that a large proportion of future growth at Gatwick will have a direct effect on Sussex. At least half the people who work at Gatwick live in Sussex and it is inevitable that that proportion will rapidly increase within the next five or 10 years.
For the sake of Crawley it is vital that planning needs and the organisation of public services should be totally integrated with the same authorities as Gatwick. With the best will in the world, it would not be in the interests of Gatwick or Crawley if they were under the control of different authorities. I hope that the Under-Secretary will resist the Amendment.

After 20 hours I intend to make the shortest speech of the night. We must stop thinking about shuffling aircraft noise around and get down to the basic problem of curing it at source. I was brought up in Sussex and I have seen the Crawley and Gatwick area change so much over the years that I
cannot help but feel that the Sussex case is a very strong one.

I will be brief in answering the debate because many other figures and much of the case I wish to put have been put by my hon. Friend the Member for Horsham (Mr. Hordern). I do not quarrel with any of the figures he gave. I pay a particular tribute to my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking (Sir G. Sinclair), for the way in which he presented his case not only in the House today but to my colleagues and my hon. Friends over the last few months. He has been the dynamo behind the extremely efficient and effective campaign to ensure that Surrey's case has been constantly before us. Nevertheless I shall have to disappoint him for reasons that have emerged from the debate. I cannot advise the House to accept the Amendment.
There have been one or two references about the position of Surrey and the comments of Sir Jack Longland and other people that we need strong counties around London, and we agree with that. But one might almost get the impression that Surrey is moving into the Rutland category. In 1951, excluding areas lost to London, the population of Surrey was 750,000. The population today is a million and it is still expanding very rapidly. The rateable value of Surrey is £59 million and of West Sussex £29 million. The rateable value for Charlwood and Gatwick is about £577,000 so Surrey is not yet on the breadline.
Even with the single runway at Gatwick there is bound to be a dramatic increase in employment and all the supporting services in the area. All the other likely needs for supporting this massive increase in passenger movement and employment are bound to have a substantial effect and are bound to strain the substantial resources in the area. The critical point is that the Redcliffe-Maud Commission said that the area had to be looked at and planned as a whole. I believe that was the view of the right hon. Member for Deptford (Mr. John Silkin) when we debated the matter in Committee.
Since Redcliffe-Maud said that, the South-East Strategic Plan has been pub-
lished and it is quite clear that the growth area has been defined and backed by the Government as Gatwick and the area to the south, not to the north. That is the whole basis of the planning argument when considering the tremendous strains and pressures which will be involved at Crawley with the expansion of employment and the expansion of Gatwick Airport. My hon. Friends who put the case for Surrey so well did not meet that essential point. The Government are not being difficult for the sake of being difficult in coming to this very complicated decision.
Is my hon. Friend the Under-Secretary suggesting that development to the south will not take place if Gatwick remains in Surrey?

I am not suggesting that. My hon. and gallant Friend has varied the question which he put to my hon. Friend the Member for Horsham. If there is to be substantial development, which I think everyone accepts, and if it is to be biased to the south rather than to the north, from every possible point of view it makes sense as Redcliffe-Maud argued, and as the right hon. Member for Deptford and the Government have argued, to have one planning authority. It is even more important in the light of the changes taking place in planning procedures and structure plans and so forth.
When we refer to planning we do not mean an archaic person sitting in a back office drawing up maps. Planning involves housing and commercial and industrial development and all the other things that make life worthwhile. That is why there is so much emphasis upon planning within the Bill and within other Bills going through Parliament.
My hon. Friend the Member for Brighton, Kemptown (Mr. Bowden), made the important point that although Gatwick is called "London Airport, Gatwick", it is not an airport for London only but serves the whole of the South East, and it will undoubtedly have considerable growth potential notwithstanding the developments taking place at Maplin.
I do not wish to be difficult about the villages which were mentioned by my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking. My hon. Friend the then Under-Secretary
of State for the Environment said in Committee: If we have to make up our minds about Gatwick, which I think it right that we should, Gatwick should be associated with the nearest major urban area, which is that of Crawley. This leaves what I would regard as a regrettable option, if it were to be exercised, by the people of Horley and Charlwood, that they should be dissociated from the airport in another county. If they felt particularly strongly about being in Surrey, that would be an option for them,"—[Official Report, Standing Committee D, 27th January, 1972; c. 1029.] As I understand the situation the people of Horley and Charlwood villages, having been given this option, the people of Horley felt unable to take a decision and the people of Charlwood were not able at the present time to express a view, partly because of the uncertainty about the future boundary of the airport. I received a letter yesterday from Mr. Epson. I am sure he will not mind my explaining the main purport of it. He is the Chairman of the Horley and Charlwood Protest Committee and also, I believe, Chairman of the Charlwood Parish Council. He says that the people of the area share overwhelmingly the wish to stay in Surrey. The second point he makes is that the parishes of Horley and Charlwood are so dominated by and inextricably mixed with the airport that it would be a planning disaster to separate the two. Mr. Epson is obviously speaking on behalf of the Protest Committee and is clearly not speaking on behalf of the individual parish councils.
I do not think that the matter should drag on leaving the option open for ever and a day. That would not be a good thing for the local people or for the sort of conclusions we must reach. If it is helpful, accepting that Charlwood still has an open option, I am prepared to consider representations from Horley within a reasonably short period of time.
I am grateful for the undertaking my hon. Friend has given.
It would set a very great difference between the two areas if they did not receive equal options on this case.
12 noon

My hon. Friend will understand that although I am not setting a definite time limit, there must be one, for everybody's sake. No doubt those concerned will read the report of this debate.
Many of my hon. Friends have mentioned the suggestion, attractive at first sight, of leaving the whole question for the first review under Clause 50 in 10 to 15 years' time. The Maplin development would then be completed, with aeroplanes flying there and so on. That suggestion, which would merely delay the evil day before taking a decision, putting the planners in the area in an impossible position, was shot down by the figures given by my hon. Friend the Member for Horsham. If we accept that there is to be considerable development at Gatwick, and if it is to be biased to the south, we cannot put the local authorities in the area in the position of having the matter in deep freeze for another 10 or 15 years. Both in principle and practice that would not be good.
It is getting very late. I have tried to sum up the overwhelming planning arguments. They are not just bureaucratic bumbledom. It is not that we are not conscious of the real human feelings of the people living in the area, which were well expressed by my hon. Friend the Member for Dorking and others of my hon. Friends from Surrey. At the end of the day, for the sake both of the people living in the area and of the massive developments in an important growth area in the South-East, I must advise the House to reject the Amendments.

speech.p: 1.— (1) The English Commission shall consult the councils of existing counties, boroughs and urban districts and the committees established under section 252(1)(b) above with a view to making proposals to the Secretary of State for the constitution of parishes having boundaries co-terminous with those of existing urban districts and boroughs, and for naming those parishes. (2) The Secretary of State may give the Commission directions for their guidance in making any such proposals.

3. The constitution of an area as a parish under this Part of this Schedule shall not affect—
(a) the continued existence, subject to section 1(9) above, of the borough or urban district the area of which is co-extensive with that of the parish, or

I preface my remarks by saying that the area under discussion is part of my constituency at Dagenham although it is now in the borough of Redbridge and will be transferred to another constituency at the next General Election.
In 1967 the Greater London Council brought forward a proposal for building a caravan site mainly for the use of foreign visitors to London in Hainault Forest, in a primitive part of the forest which has never been reclaimed or destroyed and which is an area of great natural beauty. This proposal was defeated by the collaboration of various Members of Parliament for the area concerned and the idea was dropped.
Now another proposal has come forward from the Greater London Council to build a similar caravan site for foreign visitors to London nearby the original Hainault Forest site in an area called Hainault Lodge. This is a wooded piece of land at the top of a hill, one of the few wooded areas one comes across travelling from east London. It is 16 acres and it encloses a Victorian building and a modern house. This has been used for many years by Oldchurch Hospital as an annexe for old people. It is now surplus to requirements and has therefore passed to the Department of the Environment to decide what the future use of the site shall be. The GLC hopes to acquire it and to use it for the purpose of a caravan site. It hopes in this way to be able to by pass Parliament, which it had not been able to do on the earlier occasion.
The Department of the Environment owns the site. It is responsible for deciding what its future use shall be and it is responsible for the house, I am asking
that it should not make it available to the Greater London Council for use as a caravan site but should consider other, more suitable, uses.
My main case against the use of the site for caravans is, first, on safety grounds. The main road, the B174, comes up from Dartford Tunnel and the industrial area of Dagenham to the north and connects with the A10 and All and what will be the M10. From the top of the hill down, the road is being put into dual carriageway. There is a great deal of industrial traffic using the road. It is a dangerous road for children living in the Hainault Estate on one side, who have to cross to the playing fields and the forest on the other. It is particularly dangerous because the proposed entrance to the site for caravans is from Forest Road. There is a T-junction where it meets the B174 just over the top of Hog Hill. Traffic comes up the hill at great speed and is suddenly confronted with the T-junction. If the proposal is accepted, then at this point there will be considerable numbers of foreign cars, particularly in the summer season, trying to keep to the left, with caravans in tow, and to turn off the road. It is at this particularly dangerous point from which they will try to turn off to enter the caravan site. That is one of the strongest arguments why the site should not be used for caravans.
The T-junction is also a point where horses cross the road in large numbers. The whole of the Hainault Forest area, part of which is forest but a good deal of which is taken up by a golf links and open country and so on, all belonging to the GLC, is used extensively for horse riding by young children. The horses are kept on the other side of the road and they cross at this point a good many times during the day. That is another hazard from the point of view of the use of this site for caravans.
I do not dispute that there is a need for more caravan sites for the use of foreign visitors visiting London. Anyone who has been abroad and seen the facilities there will agree with that. However, I suggest that this is not the best site for foreign visitors to London to put their caravans. Essex is already well provided with caravan sites in that area. I have a letter, dated 28th June, from the
manager of the Grange Farm Camping and Sports Centre, in which he says: I would, however, dispute the strategy of locating a new site at Hainault Lodge. This would mean three sites, ourselves, Debden Green and Hainault Lodge, all in this North-East corner of the London approaches. The Caravan Club site at Abbey Wood is in the South-East. The imminent closure of the Crystal Palace site will leave a complete vacuum… in the centre of London and the whole of the western area of London. The letter continues: At the time of writing we are in daily touch with the London Tourist Board, at their request, to acquaint their Information Services as to availability of space. The situation, this very morning, is that the Crystal Palace site is full to capacity, with caravans so close together that they have difficulty in opening doors, whilst at this site —the Grange Farm camping site at Chigwell— we could absorb another 300 units in comfort. There is no immediate need for a caravan site in this area. If it is desired at a later date to have caravan sites provided to the east of London for people coming from the continent, the important point is that they will want facilities to get into central London easily. These facilities are not provided by the Hainault Forest site. The GLC should consider possible sites along the Ongar railway route, which the Department of the Environment is subsidising to keep open. Along that route, many coal yards are vacant or are about to become vacant which would provide ample space, with firm hard core bases, from which people could get into the centre of London by the railway. It would add to the receipts of the railway if the route were used by tourists to get into central London and back again.
There is a much stronger case for putting caravan sites to the north-west of London, where they can serve not only possible visitors from the continent but people from the provinces coming to visit London. That suggestion should be investigated by the Greater London Council.
There is a strong case for Hainault Lodge to be used for an old people's home, either by the Borough of Redbridge or by the Borough of Barking. The Borough of Barking was considering taking it over at an earlier stage
before it was obtained by Oldchurch Hospital, but negotiations fell through. The house has already been used as an old people's home. There is ample room for rebuilding without spoiling the amenities, and it would not produce any of the dangers to the area which the proposed caravan site would produce. Access is fairly easy by bus, either from Ilford or from various parts of the Borough of Barking. There is a good bus service which stops at the entrance. Local communications are good, whereas they are not good for travel to central London, which is an important consideration for people from the continent who want to get into central London. Bus routes 62 and 247 come to the area from Dagenham and Barking, and these would provide good opportunities for visitors to old people if the site were so used. I hope that the Department will consider approaching the Redbridge Council or, failing that, the Barking Council to see whether the site could be used for that purpose. It seems a far more suitable purpose than that of a caravan site.

As this has not been a short sitting, I shall not detain the House for long. However, as Grange Farm, Debden Green and Ongar are all in my constituency, I should like to support the hon. Member for Dagenham (Mr. Parker). As the hon. Member said, we have been associated before in the defence of Hainault Forest. I hope that all hon. Members who live in that part of England, irrespective of party, will always be ready to work together in defence of our beauties and amenities.
The hon. Member for Dagenham has read out a letter from the manager of Grange Farm, so it is hardly necessary for me to say anything except to emphasise the point that there are spendid facilities at that site. That is all I need say, except to assure my hon. Friend the Under-Secretary of State that the hon. Member for Dagenham has my full support.

speech.speakername: The Under-Secretary of State for the Environment (Mr. Keith Speed)
speech.p:
I thank the hon. Member for Dagenham (Mr. Parker) for raising this subject. I have also noted the comments of my hon. Friend the Member for Chigwell (Mr.
Biggs-Davison). Perhaps I may start by telling the hon. Member for Dagenham the exact legal procedure regarding the ownership of the land. I thought of interrupting his speech but considered that would be discourteous. The hon. Gentleman appears to be under a misapprehension. The powers of my Department are extremely limited in this matter. Hainault Lodge is in the ownership of the Department of Health and Security. Under Treasury instructions, the Department of the Environment is a central agency for circulating Government Departments and local authorities with details of all spare Government land. It has no more standing than an estate agent. It does not own the land, the house, or anything on the land.
Hainault Lodge came to the Department of the Environment for processing. The Redbridge Borough Council, the Greater London Council and Government Departments were accordingly notified, so Redbridge has been notified. Only the GLC responded and the Department of Health and Social Security as the owning authority, was advised. It assumes responsibility for negotiating the sale terms and we in the Department of the Environment cannot express an opinion on the suitability of the proposed use. We merely act as an agency under the Treasury rules, and under those same rules the Department of Health and Social Security, or whatever Government Department is the owner, is obliged to negotiate with the body responding to the circular notice.
Part of the agency work which we do in these matters is to sort rival bids for Government land as between Departments, or in London, for instance, the competing claims of perhaps a local housing authority, the GLC and a Government Department. In general, Government Departments tend to have priority choice, but London housing use has special claims. As there is only one respondent in this case, obviously we put it in touch with the Department of Health and Social Security and that is why the negotiations are going on. We have no further locus in the matter in choosing one would-be buyer as opposed to another.
I understand that the GLC, having exercised its power to acquire this property, intends to lease the site to an exempted
organisation for use as a caravan site. No planning application is involved because use of land for a caravan site by an exempted organisation for recreational purposes—and that is important—is permitted under Class XXII of the Town and Country Planning General Development Order, 1963. The exempted organisation would be the holder of a certificate granted under the Caravan Sites and Control of Development Act, 1960, by the Secretary of State or his predecessor, the Minister of Housing and Local Government, exempting the organisation from the need to obtain a caravan site licence for the recreational use of a site for caravan purposes under the supervision of the organisation.
I stress the term "recreational use", because it is significant. By implication, it limits the use of the site to short-stay caravans as opposed to the permanent siting of caravans for residential use. I understand—and this is a matter for the Department concerned; we have no locus in it—that the GLC is concerned that the facilities available for short-stay caravanners in the London area are grossly inadequate compared with the facilities offered by other capital cities. The present level of provision is insufficient to meet current demands which are on the increase, particularly from foreign tourists. It also regards the provision of caravan sites as helping to relieve pressure from tourists for low-priced hotel and other residential accommodation in central London.
The hon. Member mentioned the Ongar rail route. This is a matter for the GLC. However, I understand that much of the route is outside the GLC area and no doubt that is something which it would have to bear in mind.
The GLC has no power to operate caravan sites itself, but it seeks opportunities to use its resources to purchase suitable sites, which it is trying to do in this case, for leasing to approved organisations. I understand that so far the council has not found it practicable to work to an overall strategy on the location of caravan sites because of the difficulty in finding suitable sites for acquisition by agreement. However, when deciding on the suitability of sites, strategic planning considerations are taken into account.
The hon. Gentleman mentioned the traffic dangers, about which he was particularly worried. Romford Road is being dualled and improved. It is a Redbridge Borough Council principal road for which my Department is paying a 75 per cent. grant. Romford Road is a busy highway and there may be some traffic management problems. This is a matter for the local highway authority, but I understand that the access to the site will be from Forest Road and not Romford Road. No doubt the GLC will take that into consideration.
Turning to the amenity considerations. I am told that the site should be well screened by trees and therefore its obtrusion on the open countryside scene should be minimal. I understand that the GLC proposes, by way of the lease, to secure the retention of a substantial tree belt and special groups of trees. The Council hopes that this transit caravan site will be a model of its kind and perhaps worthy of a civic design award.
The only possible power which we have—I do not wish to be unhelpful, but this is the legal position—lies in the matter of an Article 4 direction. There are powers in the Town and Country Planning General Development Order, 1963, which enable the Secretary of State for the Environment to make a direction withdrawing a permission granted by the Order. But this is treated as a reserve power which, as a matter of policy, is very rarely used. In practice, Article 4 proceedings are initiated by the local planning authority which has to obtain the Secretary of State's approval before the direction becomes effective.
I understand the hon. Gentleman's concern about this development and his natural concern about the road traffic aspect. I do not know whether he has been in touch with the GLC. I have had discussions with the council. I do not wish in any way to pass the buck, but the GLC has the power and it is negotiating with the Department of Health and Social Security, which is the owner of the building.
As I have said, our standing in this matter is essentially that of an estate agent working under firmly laid down rules by the Treasury as to the bodies
to which we can or cannot circulate details of spare Government land and buildings. The GLC has power under the various development Acts and orders to carry out this sort of development. Therefore, any questions or criticisms which the hon. Gentleman might wish to
raise should properly be directed to the GLC and not to the Department of the Environment.
